text: Before opening, given that troubling news of the torture and killing of citizens of that Republic due to their sexual orientation from Chechnya through the press, I wanted to ask the Chechen authorities to provide the international community with precise and detailed information as soon as possible on whatis happening, confirming that the European Parliament strongly condemns all kinds of persecution and discrimination against people because of their sexual, racial, religious and political orientations.This is true within the European Union, but we also defend our values outside the borders of our Union.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen!Today is Roma Day and a special opportunity to remember once again that we in the European Union are a community of values, that everything that happens in the world must be approached accordingly and that we care about whatin the world happens to minorities, to those who think differently.We always have to find very clear words.

name: Pál Csáky
text: author. - Madam President, Colleagues. We celebrated International Roma Day on 8 April, and as part of this, together with most of my political groups, we addressed a question to the Commission and the Council, together with several of my colleagues. The “EU Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies” adopted in 2011 was very timely, and I think I am speaking on behalf of many when I say that we have high hopes for it. For me, as a politician representing the Hungarian minority in Slovakia, this framework is also important because it gives hope that it can serve as a model for the development of a universal framework for the protection of national minorities in the near future. Indeed, I am convinced that the protection of European values ​​is important in such a changing world in which we live, and that the protection of indigenous minorities must be a key element of this line of thought. Part of this is paying attention to Roma societies and taking steps to solve their problems. Let the representatives of the honorable European Commission also draw my attention to two priorities. The first is the existence of so-called Roma settlements, also in three European Union countries where this is a serious problem. In the eastern part of Slovakia, the country I come from, there are several such Roma settlements where the Roma live in conditions unworthy of Europeans. But there are also such settlements in Romania and Bulgaria, respectively. I have been the Deputy Prime Minister of Slovakia for eight years, we have been trying to take steps to eradicate these settlements, and I think that should be continued, perhaps with the creation of a European Roma Fund. The other top priority should be to support education and training programs. I wish the Commission every success in this, and I think I can promise the support of all of us.

name: Soraya Post
text: author. – Madam President, to make a tangible progress in our fight against anti-Gypsyism, which is at the root cause of the situation of the Roma today, we call for a project team on Roma issues to be set up, bringing together Commissioners Jourová, Thyssen, Crețu, Navracsics, Andriukaitis and Hahn, to create non-discriminatory and complementary EU funds and programmes. We call for the continuation of the EU-Roma framework after 2020, building on the findings and recommendations of the Court of Auditors, the FRA, NGOs and watchdog organisations. We call on the Commission and the Member States to make sure that the projects financed by the EU are inclusive and fight segregation. Segregational practices must be clearly described and explicitly excluded from funding.  As we concede that most mainstream programmes systematically fail to reach out to young Roma, we call on the Court of Auditors to check the employment and education programmes of the EU. We call for anti-Gypsyism to be put in the focus on the national Roma strategies, and anti-discrimination indictors to be introduced in the relevant fields. We call on Member States to design their country strategies on the basis of consultations with Roma representatives and pro-Roma NGOs, and then involve them in the running, monitoring and evaluation of the projects.  We call on the Commission to set up a truth and reconciliation commission at EU level and in Member States, to set up such commissions at national level, to acknowledge this persecution, exclusion and disownment of the Roma throughout the centuries. To document this in an official white paper and to make their history become part of the curriculum in schools. We call on Member States to mark 2 August as Roma Holocaust Memorial Day. These steps are absolutely necessary to fight successfully against anti-Gypsyism.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Author. - Madam President! The Serbian Rom Rajko Đurić wrote in one of his books: One day God decided to create man. He took clay, made a figure out of it, and put it in a vessel to burn into clay. Then he went for a walk, and when he came back the man was completely black. He became the ancestor of the blacks. God tried again to create a human being and again formed a figure and put it in a vessel to be burned into clay. Then he opened the vessel a little early and this person was all white and the ancestor of white people. Eventually he decided to create a third human, and this was the color of the two. He became the ancestor of the Roma. This myth that people are different, but ultimately of one God, did not make it into the lullabies of the children of Europe. Somehow between the bigger picture, black and white, Roma and Sinti seem to have been lost, as if they were a negligible minor matter. They have disappeared behind Brexit and refugee flows, household figures and forecasts as if they were superfluous. In some places it has been forgotten that they too belong to the intertwined of all racisms. Porajmos with 500,000 people from their community who did not survive 1945. If we speak here today on the occasion of Roma Day, it is because almost all promises made to Roma and Sinti have not been kept, because we owe it to them to finally work with them to achieve justice - justice to one of the oldest minorities in Europe. Freedom and justice, freedom, equality and fraternity - including sisterhood - must also apply to Roma and Sinti. Not anytime, but now, immediately, everywhere. Roma and Sinti are not petitioners. They do not have to justify their demands. We have failed too many generations of Roma and Sinti calmly.Let's finally start working off our debt to them.

name: Benedek Jávor
text: author. - Madam President, honorable Members. On the occasion of the Roma Day on April 8, we organized the Roma Week in the European Parliament for the second time this year, which provided an opportunity for a number of extremely high-quality and interesting programs, conferences and exchanges. Roma Day and Roma Week, Roma culture, the celebration of Roma identity, the opportunity to celebrate Roma pride. At the same time, we also have the opportunity to point out the problems that the Roma community in Europe and the Member States has to face to this day. The fact that this is a European Roma strategy in the Member States and the multitude of programs implemented by the Union, despite the money spent on the ground, the situation of Roma communities in the field has not improved in recent decades. Everyday experience continues to be various forms of segregation, education, health, housing segregation, the impossibility of accessing the labor market, the fact that EU funds often do not help, although targeted, do not help the integration of Roma communities, but sometimes the opposite. achieve an effect. It also points out that fundamental EU provisions, values, rights and rules are not being implemented. That's why we can't sit back! We need to draw attention to the fact that we must continue to take action against segregation, anti-Roma and all forms of racism. We need to implement existing legislation and force Member States to respect EU fundamental values ​​and EU fundamental rights, in all cases with regard to the Roma minority, the Roma community. Ladies and gentlemen, Europe has many problems and we are debating a lot about how to make this community a success. However, we must agree that without the integration of the Roma community, without the success of the Roma community, neither Europe nor its Member States will ever be able to succeed.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission strongly condemns all forms and manifestations of racism and xenophobia, including anti-Gypsyism. It is indeed a root cause of Roma social exclusion and discrimination and it hampers the efficiency of policies which have been put in place. The Commission is addressing the issue by a holistic approach through the enforcement of legal policy and financial instruments. We have stepped up our efforts to ensure the correct implementation of anti-discrimination legislation including the Racial Equality Directive, as well as the Framework Decision against Racism and Xenophobia. We have launched infringement proceedings against three Member States on discrimination against Roma children in education. The Commission considers that education is a powerful tool to promote citizenship and the common values of freedom, tolerance and non-discrimination. In this context, the Commission will propose a Council recommendation on promoting social inclusion and common EU values through formal and non-formal learning before the end of this year. The Commission will also launch a new pilot action with the Council of Europe to support the integration of Roma through enhancing inclusive education. In June 2016 the Commission launched the EU High-Level Group on combating racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance. It provides best practice guidance and strengthens the cooperation between the Commission, Member States, EU agencies, relevant international organisations and civil society. This high-level group is fostering discussions on the specificities of particular forms of intolerance, including anti-Gypsyism. Following up on the high-level group’s discussion in December last year, the Commission has just published a document gathering key guiding principles on hate crime training for law enforcement and criminal justice authorities. The Commission also supports Member States and other relevant actors in their efforts to prevent and combat hate speech and hate crime. In the framework of the high-level group, the Fundamental Rights Agency established a dedicated sub-group to support Member States in defining a methodology for data collection and recording of hate crime incidents.  The Commission has also taken initiatives to ensure that illegal hate speech is countered both in the offline and online worlds. On 31 May 2016 we agreed on a Code of Conduct on countering illegal hate speech online, with Facebook, Twitter, Microsoft and YouTube. We are now evaluating its implementation by these IT companies and we will present the result of this evaluation by the end of May.  The Commission is convinced that fighting discrimination and anti-Gypsyism must go hand-in-hand with fighting Roma social and economic exclusion. This is based on the assessment made by the Commission and confirmed in the Council conclusions of 8 December last year on accelerating the process of Roma integration. These conclusions urge Member States to acknowledge the discrimination affecting Roma, to recognise anti-Gypsyism as one of its underlying factors, and to fight it. The conclusions are very concrete and comprehensive in this respect. Member States are urged to act through enforcing legislation, broad awareness, awareness raising, promoting a positive image of Roma and promoting Roma culture, language and history through school curricula, media or research. The Council conclusions also urge Member States to recognise and commemorate the victims of Roma genocide. This is also why the Commission allocated EUR 6 million as specific funding to projects promoting tolerance and fighting stereotyping, hate speech and hate crime. Another example is the two-year EU campaign ‘For Roma, with Roma’ aimed at combatting prejudices and discrimination, which ran from 2014-2016. Funding opportunities to fight discrimination are also available under the European Structural and Investment Fund where the Commission encourages Member States to involve the representatives of the Roma community in the programme’s monitoring and to promote Roma integration objectives. Finally, the Commission considers that it is our moral duty to remember all those who suffered under the Nazi regime, including the Roma. The Commission welcomed and strongly supported the initiative of the European Parliament to designate 2 August as European Roma Holocaust Memorial Day. The Commission has already encouraged Member States to do the same. The Council conclusions on accelerating the process of Roma integration also urge Member States to recognise and commemorate the victims of the Roma genocide.  The Commission will continue to support the European Parliament in its action to bring the resolution to the Council for discussion.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I have had a lot of experiences in my own life with regard to the integration of Roma, because I was previously responsible for this as minister, and frankly, I am somewhat tired of the fact that we have to keep having the debate. I would like to thank my colleagues who keep this topic on the agenda. Because the integration of Roma has still not succeeded. If eight out of ten Roma are close to the poverty line, if a third of the study participants only get paid jobs, then that shows relatively clearly where we are at the moment. If 50% of the children do not go to school at all, then the integration of the Roma has still not succeeded. I think it is essential not to dwell on mutual stereotypes: "The Roma behave as follows". You can integrate Roma if you give them the opportunity to live properly, if you work with social workers to ensure that the children go to school, if you make sure that the children also have vocational training - regardless of whether Girl or boy, because there are also different ways of handling and different problems - if you take care that the children are not abused, for example for beggar rings and the like. You can do a lot there if you want to do this. And, Commissioner, I have one request: I think statistics are wonderful, but real help is actually the essential thing that we need to move forward. That means we have to act on the part of the European Commission - that would be my request. In the end, it is not enough to let the Member States act alone, because in some Member States I have the impression that the development for the integration of the Roma is proceeding very, very slowly, and that there is maybe more support is needed, sometimes a little more pressure.Because if people live within the EU without windows, without bathrooms, without any school nearby, without any kind of perspective on life at all, then I believe that this is a very problematic constellation, which we do not just ask for an oral answer every yearto be able to operate in a new way, but where we specifically have to change our actions.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group.- It is worrying and sad that the European Union cannot boast of progress in a policy that would improve the situation of the Roma, on the contrary.In its annual report, the European Commission acknowledges that the situation is deteriorating sharply in certain countries.One in three Roma children goes to bed hungry at least once a month, and 30% of Roma households do not have access to running water.And that this is happening in Europe in 2017 is a shame.In the light of the Roma integration strategy, it is crucial to place the improvement of the lives of thousands of Roma Europeans at the heart of the Union's policy.A number of countries still do not use European money for Roma integration.And with the rise of the far right around the world, it is even more important than ever to realize the consequences of the Holocaust on the Roma: at least 500,000 Roma were exterminated during World War II.In some countries, this represented about 80% of the total Roma community.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Madam President, Honorable Commissioner, both you and I are aware that, unfortunately, Roma are associated with terms of segregation, racism, intolerance, all those terms that are directly against the values ​​of the European Union, what everyone here in this room, we want to promote, and that is just the opposite of what is stated, it is tolerance, respect for our differences. Among other things, the fact is that the Roma are the minority that suffered the most along with the Jews in the Second World War. Unfortunately, I must say that along with Nazi Germany and Ustasha Croatia, Croatia was one of those countries that showed what it means to kill people, simply because they are members of a minority that everyone hated at the time. What I want to emphasize, however, is something else. I want to emphasize that there are good examples, regardless of all the tragedies we are witnessing, there are great examples. I will dare to mention what I did when I was the Istrian prefect when I did everything I could to help the Roma. I can tell you that if we use some methods - specifically, quite specifically - if we help them with their education, if we organize special kindergartens for them, if we provide scholarships for Roma children, if we organize their media appearances to show their culture and what they really know, if we organize special councils for national minorities, if we help them in micro-entrepreneurship, if we legalize their jobs in the markets, then a lot can be done. I want to emphasize that European programs, national programs will never be fully implemented if local and regional authorities are not seriously involved. Međimurje is another, also a good example, because we have Roma settlements not only in the countries mentioned earlier, but also in Croatia. Roma settlements in Međimurje have a number of problems, but they also have good examples. In this context, I would just like to emphasize that I call on the Commission to consider how to direct European money directly to local and regional authorities, as this is certainly one of the ways in which the Roma community can be better integrated into the local or regional community.(The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: the question she asked by raising the blue card.- Mr. Jakovčić, we are not in the Croatian Parliament, but I listened to what you said and all credit to the efforts that you as the Istrian prefect have undertaken in your region and I think it is necessary to direct money to Roma communities and therefore I join your appeal.Do you consider the example of Croatia, in which we have a representative of the Roma community in the Croatian Parliament, a good example?I think this is a pretty solid example and can be called a European practice.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card.- Dear colleague, I am convinced that Croatia has definitely made a number of serious, positive steps towards all minorities, including the Roma.The fact that we have a guaranteed mandate of a member of parliament for a member of the Roma minority is something I am not sure exists in any other country of the European Union.I do not fully know this legislation, but this is certainly a great example and a way for a member of the Roma community to promote the interests of that community and show how to integrate it.

name: Tania González Peñas
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam president; «Gelem, gelem», which means «I walked, I walked»: this is how the gypsy hymn begins, some verses that draw on the nomadic history of the gypsy people and that are loaded with meaning because they are inspired by the memory of the gypsies and the gypsy victims of Holocaust Nazism. In 1971, April 8 was declared International Day of the Gypsy People, to claim their rights, and today we are here to commemorate that day - and it is very positive that it is the subject of debate in this European Parliament - but, above all, to do of loudspeakers and denounce the increase in hate crimes against the Roma community and make clear all the work that remains to be done in socio-labor policy in this regard. It's okay to have a designated day on the calendar; This gives visibility and sensitizes the population, but the Roma people have been suffering discrimination, segregation and levels of poverty and social exclusion for decades well above the European and national averages, especially when we talk about women and children. We must work with society as a whole to end negative stereotypes towards the Roma people, and the best way is to promote real and effective integration, socio-labor insertion and access to decent housing and eliminate special schools, which in some countries still segregate Roma girls and boys and put the individual and collective development of the youngest at risk. And it is essential, in this sense, to fight against institutionalized anti-Gypsyism, of which we have cases throughout Europe, in all European countries. I only mention two to finish: the Roma camps in Italy and the 2,582 Roma evicted by the security forces in France. We still have a lot of work to do from the institutions too.

name: Terry Reintke
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to tell you a story: a story about two brothers, two Roma brothers. They are about my age and grew up in a city very close to my home town. Their family came from Kosovo. When they were in their mid-20s they were deported from Germany back to Kosovo – from their home back to a country they almost did not know. They were separated from their families, their friends and their lives. Their names are Kefaet and Selami. They are two brothers, two very talented musicians who have now found their way back home and have expressed their hardship in rap music.  They are two among many who have faced discrimination in the European Union, but they are also two among many Roma and this is what we very often forget when we speak about the Roma who have resisted, and who have found a way to deal with this hardship and to say that they want to fight against anti—Gypsyism in our societies. Not only that, they want to fight for a better life, for civil rights for all, for their families, for prospects and for equality in our societies. They should be an inspiration to all of us, not only on International Roma Day, but every day, because they will be amongst the people who will shape our societies in the future. Do not be mistaken: the fight against anti-Gypsyism and against discrimination is not just something that the Roma communities have to take care of. It is something that all of us have to work for because this is not only about the livelihoods and the well-being of Roma communities; this is about our democracy. This is about whether we want to live in equal societies, so this is about our future as well. I urge you, Commissioner and all my colleagues, let us stand up against any form of anti-Gypsyism in our societies and fight side by side with the Roma people for a future of equality and democracy in the European Union.

name: Tim Aker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this debate is about Roma, but because of the EU’s four fundamentalisms – I will not call them freedoms – it is also about migration. Your cult-like adherence to complete open borders means it has to be. The EU signed its own political death warrant when it expanded to the east and brought into the EU vastly poorer former communist countries. Using EU rules, the great migration westwards began. For the first time in British recorded history, net migration to the UK soared to over a quarter of a million and as high as a third of a million recently.  One of the communities particularly hit was in Sheffield. According to reports, the Page Hall estate received an influx of 6 000 Roma and eastern European migrants in four years. Such had been the pace of migration into the UK that the then government’s integration adviser, Dame Louise Casey, was quoted to have said whole areas have changed beyond all recognition because of a failure by government to handle mass migration.  Now no one can deny anyone the ambition to get a better deal for themselves or their families, but as elected representatives we are answerable to our constituents first and foremost. My constituents watching this know that they are my boss. Like any good employer-employee relationship, if my employers do not think I am doing a good job they will remove me. This is perhaps why UKIP has won the Thurrock local elections for three years running.  What we have seen is the EU’s top-down agenda forcing change on communities that no one voted for. Let us look at the Page Hall estate again, a whole estate transformed without any one voting for it. In fact one Labour politician – yes, Labour – warned of riots due to the levels of Roma migration into Sheffield.  The knock-on effects of uncontrolled migration across the UK have seen school class sizes increase. Families struggle to get the right school place for their children; A&E waiting times are unbelievably high; the housing waiting list puts social housing beyond the reach of many of my constituents, and the pressures are always felt hardest in working class communities.  EU policies have turned a Europe of different nations and cultures into a free-for-all. It may suit the rich and wealthy to have easy access to cheap cleaners and au pairs, but working class communities have seen their neighbourhoods change and opportunities disappear without their consent. Brexit gives us a chance to change all this. If the Conservative government betray the millions of people who voted for proper border controls they will never be forgiven. We toppled one prime minister; we can do so again. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, I must say that I am very surprised that, in this important debate, where we talk about integration, opportunities for the Roma people and in remembrance of the Holocaust, the right honourable gentleman does not, with a single word, address that situation.  What he does is take on the majority position of society and blame the Roma population of Europe. You say, Mr Aker, that they are flooding your society and you are blaming poverty on the Roma people. The Roma people have been suffering all through European history but the situation has never been better. It seems like the honourable gentleman is harking back to a situation where we could address and oppress the Roma people of Europe nationally and it was hidden because we could not address it. Today, we have an opportunity to give prosperity to all of the people of Europe. Please address that in your reply and do not continue to attack the people that are moving across borders.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – I would like to thank the honourable Member for that speech. I do not know whether the translation was a bit skew-whiff, but I actually pointed out that the British Government had no integration plan whatsoever. Because of EU policies and because of complete free movement, there was no integration plan and, because of the levels of immigration into the UK, there could not have been an integration plan because the pace of change was far too quick.  That was the point I was making, so trying to paint a picture of everything being rosy in the European Union is precisely why people are fed-up with this place. Your failure to grasp this will mean that other nation states will vote to leave. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Soraya Post (S&D)
text: question (“blue card”).- You were very clear that Roma do not fit into your society.I do not understand how, totally without common sense, totally without shame, you can come in and have that debate in this room, on this issue, unfortunately.My question to you is: Did you think it was appropriate when your whole UK colonized more than half the world?

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Madam President, I am happy to e-mail the lady my speech where she can see that she was probably listening to a completely different speech. Trying to put words in my mouth, Madam, to make cheap political points actually debases this Parliament and this Chamber, which my constituents will see. Two-thirds of the people in Essex and three-quarters in my constituency of Thurrock voted to leave this place and your ramblings there, Madam, are precisely why they were completely correct to do so. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mr Aker, I think that you may be living on another planet and that not all interpreters will be able to interpret your pseudo-racist speeches.You claim that the migrants who came to the UK are all criminals, they all take jobs from the British, you are trying to persuade us.And what do you say about the case of a Czech who was beaten by a chain a few weeks ago, and a British court today acquitted the same British and said it was a necessary defense, even though we all saw in the video how he was literally beaten by three British?Aren't you ashamed of it?

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – I do not think there is anything to say to that level of rubbish. Another person trying to put words in my mouth – and you carry on doing this, carry on trying to paint everything in the European Union as rosy, keep demonising people who raise legitimate concerns.  In my speech, I mentioned the fact that the British Government had no integration plan, the fact that they had not put any plans in place to be able to manage migration when the European Union expanded. These are legitimate concerns, and are concerns that led 17 million people to vote to leave the European Union.  So, carry on, Sir, as you will; we will be out of this soon enough and you can keep talking to the echo chamber.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I would like to remind you that the first sentence of the Charter of Fundamental Rights is: "Human dignity is inviolable."That is the basis of our cooperation and our coexistence here in the European Union, and we should act on it.I also ask the following speakers to adhere to it.

name: Mara Bizzotto
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have great respect for all peoples who are victims of persecution and violence, especially those who suffered them in the Second World War. Today, however, behind the lie of inclusion, Europe spends an avalanche of money for the Roma, millions of euros that are useless, because the integration of the Roma is practically zero, because it is they who do not want to integrate. This money must be given to our citizens, to our unemployed, to our families in difficulty. Come to Italy to see how the Roma have not integrated. Ask the police, the mayors, the citizens who have the misfortune to live near the Roma camps. Read the newspapers, watch television, and every day you will find avalanches of news on the problems and hardships that our citizens are forced to suffer because of the Roma. And don't allow yourself to say we are racist, because we are not. We are only saying real things that happen every day. Other than international day for Roma. Rather, we should make a day for our citizens, Italian and European, who are victims of the abuses and problems caused by the Roma. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Soraya Post (S&D)
text: question (“blue card”).- You show a great deal of lack of intelligence, empathy, human dignity.Do you mean that on this day you are talking about the Roma being the cause of the situation we are in today?Do you mean that you can then sit in this House, which you absolutely do not want to belong to?Do you find it difficult to integrate yourself into EU values?Is that so?

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- So, I live in Italy and I don't live on the moon.And in Italy, every day, the police enter Roma camps, regular or irregular.And yes, they find children without shoes, badly dressed and without food.But next to them they find big cars, Mercedes, Audi, cars that have obviously been bought, I don't know how, I hope not with European funds.And this is a shame, this is a great shame!And that's that.(The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question referred in accordance with the "blue card" procedure.- Dear colleague, I am surprised that you have not listened to our President's call on human rights and the provisions of the UN Charter.You say that the Roma are to blame for this situation.Personally, what have you done, are you a member of the European Parliament, what have you done to integrate the Roma in Italy, for their education, to be able to participate in school?What child would not want to eat, what mother would not want her child to be well dressed and educated?And Roma mothers are also mothers, ma'am!

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- European funds for the integration of Roma in Italy have either been badly spent or have not been spent.Because, as I said before, Roma children in Italy don't want to go to school, because their families force them to beg or steal.I do not say this: if you want I will read the newspapers, even today in the newspapers this is written, even today it is written this.Or they all come to Italy, the worst, the worst, and the good ones come to you ... because this, unfortunately, is the simple reality.And I challenge any Italian parliamentarian to say otherwise.(The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – I have a short question. What are you doing? That is the question. That was the lady’s question. We know this, we know the stories and we can explain it, but what are we doing to improve it? What are you doing in your capacity? It is not about the European forums. What are you doing? How are you trying to fulfil the European Union’s Roma strategy for 2012? That is the question. Please give a short answer.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- As soon as I arrived here in the European Parliament in 2009, I asked how much money was spent on the Roma, because I could not understand where it was spent in Italy, because unfortunately the money for the Roma and integration did not work.But because they don't want them to integrate with us.This happens in Italy unfortunately, this happens in Italy.I would invite you, whenever you want, to come with me to the Roma camps, obviously accompanied by the police, because alone it is impossible.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I was now generous with the blue cards because it was still the parliamentary groups' speakers.From now on, however, I will only allow one blue card per speaker because I also have to look a little bit at the clock.However, I have now let it go because it is a very important debate and it also shows what the positions of the individuals are.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I think this debate shows how we simply need to commemorate this Roma Day. Before I became an EU Member and before I even started working, I worked as a streetworker for four years and worked with the Roma. It is interesting to see how their culture and how their coexistence with the majority group in Czech society changes significantly. The Roma are different, and that is what this debate is about. We must remember this otherness. The speaker said here what the Roma have problems. Yes, we can say that the Roma take drugs. They may be doing crime, but why are they doing it? That is the basic question. And the basic question is: How can we change that? There are several million Roma living in the European Union, perhaps more than some of the nationalities represented in the European Parliament. But they do not have a voice. How many MEPs are Roma here? How many people from the Roma community have established themselves here? How many people from the Roma community have the ability to study? Here we can swear and show examples that someone has a Mercedes and someone just lets the children run down the street. But why don't we also show examples of those Roma who work as police officers, lawyers, doctors who go to Italy to wipe the asses of Italian pensioners in a normal majority white society, for example. Why don't you mention this example too? And that's my question. We have heard here from a colleague from Great Britain what the Roma have caused to the problems in Great Britain. But why isn't a colleague from the UK talking about the Roma, who are normally involved in the work process and who make up British society?

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - Ms. President! We must admit with shame that it is not good to be a Roma in Europe today. Our Roma compatriots, who are citizens of the European Union with the same rights as any of us in this Chamber, face constant and constant discrimination in their daily lives. Educational segregation, forced evictions, discrimination in the labor market and health care. The European Framework Strategy Despite a number of statements, resolutions and conferences, the situation of the Roma in Europe has changed virtually nothing in recent years. That is why we do not need further debate, but political will and decisive action everywhere in Europe. For the elimination of Roma settlements, quality, empowerment education, scholarships, social care, job creation, training programs and, above all, clear and tough action against racism, anti-Gypsyism and discrimination.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, anti-Gypsyism is a major problem in the European Union. Gypsies and gypsies constitute the largest minority on the continent, and there are authorities and institutions that have policies of systematic discrimination towards them. Today, there are States of the Union like Hungary that, with a government of the European People's Party, segregate Roma students into differentiated schools. In the European Union, there are cases of discrimination and segregation in other sectors, such as healthcare or access to housing. Austerity measures are imposed by fire on the peoples of the European Union. On the other hand, the principle of equality that is contained in all the Union Treaties is ignored, and the States discriminate without the European Union doing absolutely nothing. And it is because it is a systemic discrimination that means that, in the Spanish State, only 15% of gypsies complete compulsory education, that they have an unemployment rate almost ten points higher than the average, or that one of each ten live in homes without the minimum conditions of habitability. This is a direct consequence of poverty and the stigma associated with a population that is constantly ignored and made invisible. What is not named does not exist, and that is why comprehensive recognition of Roma identity and history is essential. We have worked for the creation of this European day of commemoration of the gypsy holocaust. But, nevertheless, we fear that it will be only a cosmetic question again: when we hear MPs from the same parties that segregate boys and girls in Hungary or Slovakia say that they support these initiatives, the truth is that they remain quite empty claim.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President! We are in the middle of this year's Roma week, and it may seem strange that we need one. But for a people without their own country, without a state, for centuries affected by discrimination and persecution, it is fortunate that we have at least gotten to the point where for a week we pay attention to the Roma and the Roma culture around the world. In the Green Group, we have produced a publication ahead of this year's Roma Week, in which we analyze the current situation and what we can do to counter anti-Gypsyism in Europe from different perspectives and from different countries. It can be obtained from us. What is it that makes Roma still so stigmatized, and how can it be that our majority societies accept that an ethnic group, which has existed in our countries for many hundreds of years, is still discriminated against and discriminated against? To understand, we must go back many hundreds of years. We know that as early as the 14th century, in some European countries, Roma were enslaved and sold or exchanged at auctions. Slavery as such was not dissolved until the 1860s, but in practice survived for several more decades. These delusions, which we have heard about here before, are still deeply rooted in Europe, in almost every country. We already learn as children to believe that the Roma themselves choose to stand outside our societies, that they do not want to participate, as we heard here recently, in the common activities of society. At the same time, our decision-making has established law after law in country after country against the Roma. Not only were laws of assimilation enacted to banish or imprison them, but also laws that gave anyone the right to kill a rum by hanging or in other ways, mainly men. It is time that we in the majority take responsibility for our own actions and change our attitudes. Then we can move on.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this morning I would have expected to see this Parliamentary House engaged - 751 parliamentarians paid by European citizens, and I don't know how many paid by Roma communities - to work on concrete actions on the real problems of our European citizens, on the real fragile of our Europe. I would have expected to talk about the elderly, I would have expected to talk about the disabled, I would have expected to talk about the unemployed, young people or the real problems of this Europe, for example security: in Italy we have a home burglary every two minutes. Of this I would have expected to speak. And instead we are here talking about fake victims, fake problems, and in doing so we are certainly not credible and serious. We have a cross-eyed view: we look at what the effect is but we don't look at what the cause is. Let's not look at what Italian citizens, for example, ask themselves: what work do the Roma do? What do Roma live on? How do the new generation caravans pay, the cars? Where does the public money go to pay for the water or light of the Roma camps? Why should we have 124 illegal Roma camps in Italy out of 167? Why do the children of these communities not have the right to go to school? Why, who is behind the begging and exploitation of these minors? Here, we would have liked to talk about the problem that out of 2 400 minors in Italy who are experiencing legal difficulties, 1 500 are Roma minors. We would have liked to talk to you about this.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Firstly, I might like to remind you - and you know this very well - that there are many other meetings taking place in parallel with the plenary meetings, in which our colleagues are attending.You know that very well, and it happens to you again and again, that you do not sit in plenary all day.That is simply not possible if you do your job properly.Secondly, I have now decided that from now on I will no longer allow a blue card because something is happening here that is not good for the European Parliament's reputation.If we notice how discrimination is becoming commonplace in the statements, I cannot accept that.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Gypsies and Gypsies are full citizens of the European Union, they have their own cultural traits and share a common identity, which does not detract from their citizenship, but rather the opposite: it represents a wealth for our society. And we have made progress in the social sphere, in access to education, to the labor market, but there is still much to do and, today, interventions that we have heard here clearly give us that message. We must fight against stereotypes, against those stereotypes that attribute certain behaviors to a part of the population. It is unacceptable, it is shameful to hear MEPs say that the Roma population is the one that is stealing, it is the one that is generating conflicts. Ask yourselves and ask the public who they think are the real thieves in their country. I think it is unacceptable, that we have to fight against stereotypes, that we have to move forward together, work together for social inclusion and fight hateful messages like the ones we had to hear this morning in this Parliament.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the opportunity, unlike my Italian colleague across the floor, to mark International Roma Day and to recognise the culture and tradition of Europe’s largest ethnic minority community. Eight million Roma live within the European Union, and while the EU has developed a framework, we all know that the situation continues to be awful for the Roma community. For years the Roma community have been victims of forced assimilation. Their time-honoured culture and traditions were eroded and the cohesiveness of their communities were shattered. We also must never forget that half a million Roma were killed by the Nazis during the Holocaust. We all must work together if we want to realise the aims of the framework and to break down the prejudices that do exist towards their community. We must work to build trust among the community for the institutions within the various Member States. Is it any wonder that children do not go to school when they are faced with attitudes like those we have heard today, on a day-to-day basis?  In Ireland, two children were taken from their parents by the police. Why? Because they were blond and they could not possibly belong to the Roma family. So is it any wonder that there is no trust within the Roma community for the institutions? It is not okay that in 2017, members of the largest minority in the EU are still more likely to die early, to be illiterate and to live in squalor than the rest of the population.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, faced with the obvious situation, which the statistics also show us, with 10% of Roma children not reaching high school, with a concentration of discrimination and poverty, none of us is able to to say that today we are up to the challenge of this day. I do not need some colleague who, with absurd and unacceptable attitudes, say it in these terms, which are not worthy, in my opinion, of this discussion. But I think we know one thing: there is a commitment from the Commission, there are national strategies that we must certainly verify, also in the use of European funds, and there are very interesting experiences of inclusion, for example a pilot project that I know that in Romania has achieved a very interesting result with regards to educational inclusion. I was the regional councilor in my region and I understood a few things. First: action must certainly be done on the anti-discrimination front and on the legal level, but there is no desegregation if there are not some measures. First: involving families (with scholarships that are given to children and that involve families in responsibility, incredible results are obtained); the involvement of Roma associations and secular or religious associations that deal very proactively with them; also support measures as well as cultural mediators and teachers who have an intercultural teaching capacity. Certainly the road is long. However, it does not seem to me that the League in Italy is very committed to this.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in my north-west England constituency, there is a significant population of Roma in both rural and urban areas. For example, the annual Appleby Horse Fair in Cumbria has become one of the most celebrated Romany festivals in Europe, filmed, photographed and featuring in tourism guides. On the other hand, public perceptions of Roma are still based on disinformation.  Last year’s referendum campaign unleashed a new wave of increased hate towards ethnic minorities, with Roma communities being particularly targeted. A Roma community development worker in Manchester told me that on 24 June 2016 – the day after the referendum – a group of Roma children who used to play in a public park had disappeared from public view overnight, frightened by the rampant, unpleasant public mood towards people of different nationalities and ethnic backgrounds. Brexit has turned my country into a shameful, intolerant place and the Roma were sadly amongst the first victims. The Brexiteers, UKIP, the Conservative Government and the right-wing press must take responsibility for whipping up hatred on a scale not seen for decades. But on Roma Day, let us find ways of addressing the issue...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: - Madam President, since 2004, when I have been a Member of the European Parliament, our political group has been very interested in the issue of the Roma. We have and have even set up working groups that not only prepare missions to countries where we meet the Roma community, but also prepare concrete initiatives and suggestions on how we can help the Roma community. As a Member of the National Parliament, I myself was in very close contact with the Roma community, and I must say that we have managed to do a good job over the years - so that we do not just talk about the weak points here on the day we celebrate Roma Day. . However, it is true, and this is the task for the Commission, that a lot of money has been spent to integrate the Roma population and to educate Roma children. So my question to you, Commissioner, is: how does the Commission control how these funds have been spent, because in many cases it has been shown that these funds have been somehow deprecated or not spent for the purpose for which they were intended.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Europe has much to remember and acknowledge in order to fully reconcile itself with its largest persecuted minority along with the Jewish, also a victim of the Roma community of the Holocaust, but above all a victim of hate speech, loaded with prejudices, that we have had to hear here, shaming this House, from MEPs from the populist far right. This Parliament is the temple of the word and cannot be soiled with those infamous words that try to stigmatize an entire community that is part of the cultural and ethnic diversity that enriches the factory of complexity and diversity that is the European Union. This Parliament adopted, on April 15, 2015, a Resolution committing the Commission to try to also engage the Member States in good practices for the integration of the Roma community, which exist in the European Union, for example in my Country Spain. But what is essential is that these words finally become deeds and that we make the Roma community an example not only of self-criticism, but of lifelong learning of Europe's commitment to the promise of the European Union.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: - Madam President, the Roma are one of the largest and still inhomogeneous minorities living in Europe for hundreds of years. I must say with great embarrassment that many Roma still live in enclaves in the 21st century and in our country in Slovakia without available drinking water, electricity or asphalt roads. They live in absolute poverty without the possibility of any change. Eurofunds, which were supposed to help the Roma, are becoming the subject of corruption or inefficient use, which we are witnessing here in Slovakia again, and this is only contributing to greater segregation. Today, it is necessary to remember such historical facts as the Roma Holocaust. But it is equally important today to help the Roma, in two ways - at least that's how I see it: first and foremost, to build pre-school facilities where children acquire habits and skills that their parents did not teach them. And also to help Roma retrain as crafts or workers in the car industry who are in short supply. Work and a fair wage will ensure more dignified living conditions and restore the hope that many of them have already lost. However, I would also like to say, say it out loud and thank all the Roma who have achieved a great deal and we can say little about it: that they are people who move in the scientific field, that they are doctors, that they are teachers, that they are university professors. In Slovakia, we have the first Roma in parliament to act as a member of the National Council. So thank you to everyone who tries and has achieved something.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Dear Colleagues!We have been delayed by the rather lively debate that we have had here.That is why I will only give the floor to those who have not yet had the opportunity to express themselves in the catch-the-eye procedure that follows.I would ask the others to understand this, otherwise we will no longer get to the edge of the many requests to speak.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Ms. President! I welcome the fact that the situation of the Roma has come to the attention of the EU in recent years, and in 2013 a Council recommendation was adopted which obliges the Member States to develop national Roma integration strategies. It is to be welcomed that the 2015 Commission review identified a clear improvement in the coherence between current Roma integration strategies and EU instruments. However, in many countries, despite existing frameworks and measures, Roma continue to suffer from discrimination, marginalization and segregation. In Romania, where measures have mostly been taken to reduce the number of early school leavers, most Roma continue to be cumulatively disadvantaged and a very large proportion continue to live in exclusion and deep poverty. That is why I see the need for further, consistent steps to improve the chances of outbreaks and to end the intergenerational transmission of poverty and exclusion.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the international day dedicated to the Roma people and the fight against anti-Gypsyism is a symbolic date, just as symbolic is the commemoration of the genocide perpetrated against the Roma during the Second World War. However, they are symbols that serve to keep European society united and welcoming, where the marginalization of the Roma manifests itself in many ways, from the phenomena of ostracism, if not open violence, to an institutionalized and dangerous racism, encouraged by politicians in search of votes. The truth is that the gypsy culture is not easy to integrate, because it is based on a lifestyle very different from ours, ancient and unique in its own way. It is a culture that has a lot to offer to Europe, a culture that places great value on family ties, a sense of belonging to the community and solidarity. There is still much to be done for full integration that goes beyond the celebration of the commemorative days. First of all, a real awareness of the institutions is needed.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, on the occasion of April 8, World Roma Day, we recall the persecution and social and racial racism suffered by the Roma over time, as they were then regarded as supposedly inferior and intruders. The centuries-long detention and persecution of the Roma escalated after 1938. During World War II, the Roma were targeted for extermination and genocide by the Nazi Germans. It is estimated that the death toll of the Roma during the Holocaust approached 70% of their total population in Europe. However, the European Parliament only recognized the Roma genocide in 2011. In any case, securing resources for the smooth integration of the Roma, especially in education, training and employment, is very important.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: - Our great poet Prešeren once wrote a song in which he said: What will you teach to blossom branches, just don't teach singers to sing!I think that today's debate also includes acknowledging the Roma for their invaluable contribution and contribution to the world's cultural heritage.I think we need to respect them because they came into the world so creative and live with us.And maybe today is an opportunity to apologize to them for all the injustices they have experienced because of their way of life.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: - As a former Minister of Education, I feel obliged to say a word, two, on World Roma Day.First of all, of course, I would like to congratulate all members of the Roma ethnic group, which has, in fact, as our colleague Vajgl said, also played an important role in European history and has its place in the cultural heritage.But in this debate today, I would rather expect them to exchange good practices, what treatment some government has towards them.My government treated them extremely positively, there was a lot of innovation, we adopted, for example, the concept of a “Roma mentor”, which assumed that a few people were chosen from among the Roma to make sure that the children attendedprocess.And this institution has been extremely successful, efficient and could also be suitable for the exchange of good practices as far as Roma policies are concerned.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE).
text: - Madam President!I am saying this in your mother tongue now because what you have done is absolutely discriminatory.I got in touch with a brief question about the “blue card”, and everyone who came later and spontaneously signed up from the left accepted you and you did not allow me to speak.I think that's terrible.It's a shame because that's absolutely against this thing we're trying to do today.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Mr Hölvényi, that didn't just affect you.But I have to look at the clock.I said that only those who have not yet spoken can have their say.Others also got in touch who had already asked an interim question that did not have a say.Therefore, it is not a discrimination against you as a person, but simply an attempt to bring some order into the debate.I am sorry if you feel so concerned.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, the path ahead of us is still a long one until we see Roma treated like any other EU citizen. The change will not happen overnight, but we must not let them stop us. We have to keep steady on course with our fundamental values. The Commission will continue to work closely and to engage in dialogue with all the relevant stakeholders, including the representatives of the Roma people and pro-Roma civil society organisations. We need to ensure that all actors involved in the fight against anti-Gypsyism are supported, including by strengthening financial and policy support to civil society and national authorities. Thank you.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: - A point of order.I would like to begin by thanking colleagues who have taken part in the debate, but I would also like your support for us writing to President Tajani and telling him about and demanding sanctions against the hate speech and the discriminatory debate that was conducted by some Members today.That is unacceptable.I thank the President for the way you handled it.I think it was good.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you, Ms. Post.Anyway, I planned to bring this up in the Presidium, because it was really far-reaching.But thank you for saying this again.Thank you for this debate, which was extremely important.In fact, everyone is responsible for what they say, but can also be held responsible if it is excessive.We will then check that.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: signed up. - All people must enjoy the same rights, freedoms and treatment. The Roma are a minority like any other minority and there should be no difference between minorities or between them and the majority of the population. Personally, I think we need proper laws and fair enforcement. The Roma have certain vocations and need help. I believe that we cannot end segregation as long as EU-funded programs or national budgets are formal and as long as we have segregation by law. For example, there are parties established on the basis of ethnicity, which accentuates segregation. I am advocating for a law that does not allow the establishment of a party based on ethnicity, whatever it may be. Citizens of a country can be members of a party and can be elected. Education is deficient. The Roma ethnic group must be included in the form of common schooling with the majority of the population, not separately. I voted and supported Roma citizens for the national and European parliaments. Romania has Roma citizens in both the national and European parliaments.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: in writing.- Ladies and gentlemen, allow me to remind you that Hungary was the first to face the social problems of the Roma and to develop a long-term strategy.As part of this, in 2012, the education of Roma culture and history was included in the national core curriculum.A program to prevent Roma girls from dropping out of school was established two years ago.During the program to increase the employment of Roma women, more than 1,100 Roma women obtained vocational qualifications, and the employment of Roma women increased by 12%, and the government established a tender to support Roma cultural events.I think that Hungarian successes speak for themselves and set an example to follow.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné (PPE)
text: written. - All Europeans were born with the same rights and therefore we must fight against any kind of discrimination, including on the grounds of ethnic origin. The Roma community suffers from a job exclusion rate of more than 75%, which makes the correct implementation of the Directive on equal treatment in matters of employment absolutely necessary, as well as the reinforcement of the role of specialized NGOs to encourage their participation in the labor market, provide information on their rights and improve the collection of data related to discrimination, since in many cases the lack of trust means that no complaint is filed. However, in my opinion, the priority has to be education and training. Ensuring children's schooling, first, and avoiding school drop-outs, second, are basic requirements, as they not only improve job prospects, but also contribute to greater participation in society, ultimately reducing poverty and social exclusion. Finally, and in order to achieve a greater integration of the Roma community into society and thus contribute to ending discrimination, we must support access to decent housing.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: signed up. - I salute International Roma Day and wish this ancient people to regain their dignity and pride among the peoples of Europe. I also welcome the initiative of my colleagues in the European Parliament to ask the Commission and the Council three questions on measures taken at European level on Roma inclusion and combating discrimination against them. But when it comes to integration, we must emphasize that the effort of both sides is needed. I am convinced that the majority, the institutions of the Member States, and the European institutions can and must do more to integrate Roma and combat discrimination. But even if the majority and state institutions become, overnight, ideal, the condition of the Roma cannot be improved without a sustained effort of responsibility and self-education on their part. I would like there to be more, more active, more responsible Roma organizations that are involved in the education, integration and promotion of the Roma. I would like more and more Roma, and especially their leaders, to follow John Fitzgerald Kennedy's exhortation: "Don't think about what the country can do for you, think about what you can do for the country!" Equality or non-discrimination is affirmed by laws, but prestige and respect are gained only through one's own effort.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing - International Roma Day is a good opportunity for all of us to remember that the Roma have been an integral part of European countries for centuries. I am glad that every year on 8 April we commemorate the anniversary of the first global Roma meeting, held in Orpington near London in 1971. Although their different lifestyles, ingrained stereotypes and prejudices still create some tension between the majority population and the Roma, I think that we should see Roma Day as a good opportunity to improve relations between the majority and the Roma population. As a person from Slovakia from the Košice region, where most Roma live in Slovakia, I want to draw your attention to the fact that despite some disagreements, several Roma representatives in Roma communities engage as volunteers in church and non-profit organizations, work as field social workers, teaching assistants, and I cannot forget that some Roma are also mayors of municipalities and members of municipal councils. Despite the fact that the Roma issue is extremely difficult and has been a long-term problem in Slovakia, I must say that in the Košice region we have successful kindergartens, primary schools, community centers, municipal enterprises that perform quality work with Roma communities. I would like to take this opportunity to thank all the Roma for their cooperation so far and wish them every success for the next period.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Russia, the arrest of Alexei Navalny and other demonstrators (2017/2646 (RSP)).

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Madam President, our thoughts and condolences are with the victims and families of the atrocious terrorist attack in the St Petersburg metro this week. Nevertheless, we cannot allow this to silence our condemnation of President Putin, his leadership and foreign policy, particularly aggression regarding Ukraine and Syria. Following the revelations of corruption against Prime Minister Medvedev in a video published by Alexei Navalny last month, we saw a wave of protest against the government, largely from a new generation of Russians that wish for a better, and better governed, future for their country. The large number of arrests, including Navalny himself, reminds us all that presidential elections are looming next year. I encourage the European Union to continue to press for the release of Navalny and to keep up the political pressure in the Council of Europe in response to the trumped-up convictions we have seen levelled against Navalny in Russia, largely aimed at preventing him from standing in the presidential elections next year. We are yet to see the exact response from the Kremlin following these protests and the attacks this week, but past experience suggests to me that political capital will be sought by President Putin from this.

name: Soraya Post
text: author. – Madam President, Putin influenced the American election. He crushed opposition at home, silenced dissent. Putin had conquered Crimea and parts of eastern Ukraine. His popularity sky-rocketed.  Everyone thought he was untouchable. Then came March 2017, totally unexpected.  They used to call them the Putin Youth, young Russians who had grown up with him in power. They used to say that these youngsters only cared about their iPhones, then came March 2017. Beware, Mr Putin. You need to respect your Constitution. You need to release your political prisoners, or March 2017 will be another winter month which goes down in Russian history.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Author. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! With deep sympathy we bow to the victims and relatives of the terrorist attack in Saint Petersburg. There is a basic consensus in the European Parliament that no political goal or right legitimizes the killing of another person. And in these difficult hours for the Russian people, I propose that the vote be suspended as a token of sympathy for today. Two remarks on the matter: Firstly, despite all the criticism of the social and living conditions in Russia, which is also necessary from the point of view of our group, with all the escalations currently underway - in the end the Russian Federation remains a neighbor and sustainable solutions for international problems without and against Russia there won't be. Parliament has turned its back to the wall on Russia by freezing our channels of communication. Article 13 of the draft resolution calls for a common EU voice against Russia from the Council. I suggest starting with us. The Conference of Presidents can now and now revoke the relevant decision without any problems and bundle the numerous “private trips” by MPs that are currently taking place again into a parliamentary dialogue. Second: Human rights are indivisible everywhere and should be implemented, especially if you commit yourself to them. I don't want to see pictures of demonstrators from any country in the world who are being dragged away, like taking garbage to the recycling center. These pictures from Moscow also tell us something about respect for human dignity, the proportionality of the use of the police and the length of the routes that are still to come. I mean: Yes, corruption must be fought, among us, in our neighborhood and, of course, among our neighbors.

name: Indrek Tarand
text: author. –   Madam President, it seems to be another day on which we compete in this plenary Chamber on who articulates better phrases on Russian human rights, and as we hear there will be others who try to convince the House that the urgency must be adjourned. For me it is an oxymoron, a contradiction in terms. If something is urgent we cannot adjourn it. It is about time to stop believing in delusions such as that Russia is a democracy. It has never been one, with the exception of six months exactly 100 years ago, after the February Revolution. After that the Bolsheviks took over, and under their enlightened leadership 50 million people were killed. Mr Putin’s educational background is Bolshevist, even worse he was a KGB officer, and it is pointless to believe or hope that he has even the slightest desire to develop democracy in his country.  Let me cite you one example to show that the Bolshevist manners have survived in this country, unfortunately. When I was 16 there was an anti-Soviet demonstration in Tallinn which was obviously declared illegal by the Soviets, and their militia was commanded to attack us. We were beaten up quite severely, but we survived, thanks to help from Western countries, the European Union, the American Government, etc. And later they sent commissars to school to explain that the youth had protested because they were promised US dollars. Mr Peshkov explained it 40 years later in the same way. Shame!

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: author. – Madam President, thousands of Russians joining the protest across the whole country in reaction to Alexei Navalny’s investigation of state corruption, and, sorry to say, typical behaviour from the EU – no action! A press release by the External Service and a resolution by this House – is that all we are up to? It is not enough! A laundromat of Russian officials’ corrupt money: this is what Europe has become. A safe haven to turn dirty, stolen money into mansions, yachts and vineyards in London, Nice and Sardinia. Calling an investigation commission based on the Navalny report: this is what the EU action must be. This is what ordinary Russian people expect from the West, as it is the money illicitly taken from them. As long as we in the EU do not fight the Kremlin’s corruption, our policy vis-à-vis Russia is simply doomed. Silence and inaction will make us partners in crime, with no right to criticise.

name: Tunne Kelam
text: author. – Mr President, freedom of assembly is a right, not a privilege, and this must be our message to the Russian authorities who have recently arrested more than 2 000 anti-corruption demonstrators through massive police operations, among them presidential candidate Alexei Navalny. But these are not occasional cases of state violence and injustice. We must understand the deepness of desperation that brought these tens of thousands to challenge the brutal force of the state apparatus. Russia has the largest gap between the richest and the poorest: 110 individuals around Mr Putin control 35% of state riches. We demand the immediate release of Alexei Navalny and other demonstrators, and postponing today’s vote would be a betrayal of these courageous citizens.  Our call is to the Commission and Member States to take systematic concentrated action against Russian money laundering and illegal assets inside the EU. It is also high time for the Council to adopt the Magnitsky sanctions, following the European Parliament’s resolutions to establish a common EU list of Russian officials who are responsible for the deaths and attacks against Russian whistle-blowers, but also of those who have illegally detained and sentenced human rights activists like Mr Navalny.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, after the bombing in St. Petersburg, we are, of course, in solidarity with Russian citizens and especially with the families of the victims. We also feel solidarity with the thousands of people who took to the streets of several cities in Russia at the end of March, at the beginning of April, to show their disagreement with the corruption that affects several leaders in Moscow, leaders who are happy of total impunity, because justice is under Putin's control. Russian citizens are not blind, they decided to act taking all risks, as has been said, two thousand arrests. Of course, as Indrek Tarand pointed out earlier, which Putin claims, the fact that children are paid to go to the rally, for example, is ridiculous. Unfortunately, I must tell you that this rhetoric was also used by a government in the European Union, by the social-democratic government in Romania, which said the same thing about the recent protests in Bucharest and other cities in the country. Here are the relatives we find between Russia and one of the member countries of the Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: Question referred in accordance with the "blue card" procedure.- Dear colleague, I want to ask you if you do not think that the European Union should take a very strong position, asking Russia if it still considers itself part of the international community, because Russia does not respect international treaties and international agreements to which it is a party.and the rights of the citizen, and at the same time do you not think that the European Union should have a strong position on the situation of Mr Navalny, which we hope will not have the same fate as Mr Nemtsov?

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE)
text: Answer to a question addressed in accordance with the "blue card" procedure.- I thought that Mr. Frunzulică was asking me what we could do with the socialist government in Bucharest.His questions are almost rhetorical questions.The more serious issue is that in the Security Council, Russia blocked yesterday a resolution introduced by a member state of the Union, France, and the American administration, because after the chemical attack in Syria there is a need to act immediately.We also remember that in 2013 the question was raised for the first time to intervene if a chemical attack occurs.

name: Kati Piri
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. In several Russian cities, tens of thousands of people took to the streets last week to join the so-called marches against corruption, the largest anti-government demonstrations in years. The protesters demanded the resignation of Russian Prime Minister Medvedev, who made headlines for his exorbitant wealth as a result of widespread corruption. However, instead of his dismissal, this resulted in hundreds of innocent protesters being arrested and detained. One of them is Alexei Navalny, the man who is one of Russia's best-known opposition leaders and was once described by the Wall Street Journal as the person most feared by Vladimir Putin. That is why he must apparently be out of the picture. The arrests violate freedom of expression, one of the fundamental rights, which is also included in the Russian constitution. It is a core value in an open and free society, just like freedom of assembly and association, but even though these rights are in the Russian constitution, in practice those who rebel against the current regime in Russia are silenced with meanwhile many prisoners and even deaths. The EU last week called for the immediate release of all March 26 and April 2 protesters, but the Russian authorities refuse to do so. Russia, like any other country, must comply with its international obligations. If not, it will be up to Federica Mogherini to increase diplomatic pressure to prevent Navalny from becoming the next victim among Kremlin critics.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I pay tribute to Sergei Magnitsky, a brave Russian lawyer who exposed the biggest tax fraud in Russian history. For touching untouchables he was held in pre-trial detention, tortured, and died there. The dark revengeful face of the Russian judiciary system was shown in his being convicted after death, posthumously. I kindly ask the Chamber to recall his name in the resolution by accepting my amendment.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Recently, in the European Parliament there was an attempt to screen a film that attacked Mr. Magnicki after his death.Fortunately, it didn't happen, but it's worth remembering.

name: Ivo Vajgl
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group.- When the trace of authoritarian, violent interference in public events, in democratic standards, becomes too obvious, then we must react.The unlimited power of one man and his narrow circle of collaborators or accomplices leads to a dictatorship, and our past and present warn us where the path of such a country leads.Alexei Navalny is one of the few politicians in Russia after the fall of the Berlin Wall that stood out, and the regime struck at him and those brave people who support him.Russia, as Gorbachev saw it and Yeltsin believed in it, is no more!Putin and all those who imitate his model of governance in post-communist countries must be told: Enough!Your courts will not judge you, so you took care, and history will judge you!

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
