text: on behalf of the ENF group.- Mr President, dear colleagues, at home, in France - and therefore not in Russia -, on March 24, 2013, during a legal demonstration - and therefore not illegal, as in Russia - we are gassed, repressed, arrested,imprisoned, as was the case with Nicolas Bernard.Here in France, under the accusation of embezzlement - we are not in Russia - the main leaders of the opposition to the socialist government, Mr. Fillon and Ms. Marine Le Pen, are accused without any form of trial,and the media and legal systems are used to destroy candidates.We are not in Russia and these are not minority opponents.Mr. Preda, forgive me, but you must let me speak.On the other hand, Mr President, I just wanted to say in conclusion ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Mr President, I understand very well that you cut off a speaker who has exceeded his speaking time, except when this speaking time is monopolized by a certain number of speakers to whom you have a dutyto impose silence.In my opinion, interruptions should not count as part of a speaker's time.It’s very basic.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I know my powers and responsibilities, the MP has exceeded his time, like some other Members before.I must treat all of them equally.I am not talking about the merits of the Deputy's speech.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: -  Mister President!This Parliament would be well advised not to interfere with any internal affairs in Russia.In the case of Alexei Navalny, we should be silent, because the EU itself is not innocent when it comes to judiciary justice and the prosecution of politically dissenters.In my country, the Federal Republic of Germany, there are over 12,000 investigations every year into alleged sedition or the formation of a criminal organization.Over 1,000 patriots are jailed and sentenced each year.The supposed West is still trying to install systems that it likes according to the pattern of color revolutions in the countries of the former Eastern Bloc.Incidentally, as we saw with the externally controlled revolution on the Maidan, this did not affect corruption in Ukraine.This Parliament would be well advised not to interfere in any way with Russia's internal affairs.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, we recently adopted a resolution in support of Ildar Dadin. He was sentenced in 2015 to three years in prison for a public peaceful protest against the war. Dadin is a representative of the new Russian protest generation, whose weapons are social networks and the Internet. Only about 2% of the population in Russia used the Internet 20 years ago. Today, about 70% of Russians already use the Internet. With the help of the Internet, Ildar was liberated. His wife Anastasia launched such a campaign on social networks that he was eventually released. The Internet has become an alternative to mainstream TV media during this year's protests in March. It was used to convene demonstrations. Therefore, most of the thousands detained were young people, including fourteen-year-olds. Ildar was detained again. This time for just a few hours. I called him yesterday. "Today it looks more like a fine than a prison," he said. As if the Kremlin regime was weakening under the onslaught of the free internet. As if relieving the young Russians. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI)
text: blue-card question. – Only one short question: have you ever heard about the clan of Mr Igor Sechin, the President of Rosneft?

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- He didn't hear.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the Putin regime is laundering money but also laundering brains through Kafkaesque propaganda. The Putin regime assassinates and detains free people and detains political opponents. The Russian "Laundromat" laundered $ 20 billion in 2010-2014 alone, involving a Putin cousin, involving companies and money and people from the Russian Federation, and also involving offshores. and European companies. Free people who demonstrated against corruption were detained, subjected to acts of violence. A top university in St. Petersburg was left without a license two weeks ago because, isn't it ?, education creates free people and a dictatorship is not based on free people. That's why I wonder: was the St. Petersburg bombing real or was it directed? Because the death of fourteen people for Putin means nothing to maintain his dictatorship. It must be very clear to all of us, it is a dictatorship with which we have no other way to speak than from democracy to dictatorship, no other negotiation will be successful.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Mr. President, it is very possible that the arrest of Mr. Navalny and the ban on the demonstration he was leading are regrettable; we do not have the point of view of the Russian government. But what I can say is that in my country, France, in Lyon for example, the Prefect Carenco was not shy about banning the demonstrations of young nationals, many of whom were arrested and even sentenced without that moving. no one. In Germany, where the President praised us yesterday for respecting human rights, there are nearly 1,054 prisoners of conscience and 12,000 people who are currently being prosecuted. So, in a nutshell, I would prefer that we sweep in front of our door. I cited yesterday the cases of an 88-year-old scholar, a father of a large family and a well-known polemicist who were sentenced to prison in procedural conditions which do not respect the rights of the defense, but that does not move the majority of this assembly.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I want to support the motion for a resolution, which I find very balanced and correct. We clearly condemn the Putin regime's crackdown on peaceful demonstrators who pointed to huge corruption in Russia's ruling oligarchy. It is quite clear that the basic constitutional human freedoms - freedom of assembly, freedom of expression - do not apply in Russia at the moment, and it is also quite clear that the judiciary there is not independent but clearly subject to the influence of the ruling regime and clearly serves Mr Putin. But what is important, which should not fit in with the condemnation of how the Russian regime behaves, is that it is money laundering. This is a huge corruption of Russian politicians. Here in the resolution, a very important point is when we call on the European Commission and the other executive bodies of the European Union to do their utmost to ensure that Russian politicians and officials cannot launder money within the European Union. This is very important, everything must be done to ensure that European banks, European companies, are not used to legalize the money of the people who serve the Putin regime. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question referred in accordance with the "blue card" procedure.- Actually, I wanted to ask my former colleague a question, but I take advantage of the fact that you have spoken and supported your proposal, but do you think that in its current form, in the current Commission regulations, we can really put an end to abuses in Russia?Don't you think that money laundering should be treated in relation to any other country, but now speaking of Russia, much more rigorously and with concrete effects?

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Of course, the public authorities cannot completely eliminate this form of crime, but we can reduce this illegal form of crime a lot.It would be great if the Commission came up with concrete proposals and specifically discussed in plenary here how the European administration can fight money laundering not only, say, European Union bodies, European Union citizens, but mainly from politicians and, say, officials who serveexternal regimes, such as the regime in Russia.So it would be good if we discussed this in a separate proposal so that it does not fall into place.Today we are talking about condemning the Russian regime, but let us talk about the concrete steps we will take against money laundering.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in early March, Alexei Navalny - who heads the Foundation for the fight against corruption - had the courage, through a video, to once again denounce the corruption of the Russian elite and of entrepreneurs close to the Kremlin. His film has given rise to the biggest protests since Putin returned to the presidency in 2012 and took thousands of people to the streets of Moscow and eighty other cities in the country. Following these demonstrations, around 800 people were detained in the capital alone, including Alexei Navalny himself. As Vice President Mogherini herself stated, these arrests clearly violate the rights to freedom of expression, association and peaceful assembly, guaranteed by the Russian Constitution, and therefore these detained protesters must be released immediately and unconditionally. I would like to conclude by saying that these protests showed the world that, despite Vladimir Putin ruling Russia for seventeen years, without giving rise to any opposition worthy of the name, there is now a younger generation at the forefront of the challenge who, never having known another leader in his life, leaves the state of apathy and is ready to fight for a more transparent and more democratic Russia.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the weaker the European Union is, the more silent it is, the more blind it is, the less responsive it is, the stronger the Kremlin will be, the more harassment we will see and witness, and I am afraid one day we might see again an opposition politician or maybe an anti-corruption activist shot somewhere by a bridge. That is a reality. What was the reaction of the European Union to the recent harassment? What is the strategy of the European Union? I call upon us, after we pass this resolution, to have a serious debate here in the plenary in Parliament, to have a strategy vis-à-vis Russia. I am not targeting Russia, I am targeting the Kremlin, the practices, the abuse of human rights. At the same time, I can see opportunities vis-à-vis SMEs, civil society, and Russian citizens. There is something that we can do and also split the Kremlin from its citizens. That is the way to proceed.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: - Dealing with peaceful protesters cannot be justified in the 21st century.History shows that there are two paths to the development of civilization.One, based on democracy, respect for political and civil liberties, leads to long-term stability and prosperity.The search for another path usually ends in economic turmoil, repression, and often armed aggression against neighbors.The answer to the question of what Russia is on is, I think, clear.Recent protests show that there are people in Russia who love freedom and are willing to sacrifice for it.Our task as Europeans is to promote democratic forces while punishing aggressive authoritarian leaders.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the European Parliament is once again raising its voice to support those who risk their lives in Russia for democracy and freedom. Unfortunately, Putin rules and uses all means to suppress the opposition. Yes, Mr Taranda, there is no democracy in Russia, but one hundred years after the Bolshevik revolution, it is time for Russia to wake up and for people to be free. There are people in Russia who are willing to take risks and make personal sacrifices. I respect them and I am very pleased that the European Parliament wants to stand up for them. Mr Navalny is indeed an opposition politician who clearly threatens Putin and is therefore being persecuted. What a contrast to life in the European Union, where people in our Member States live freely and can express their opposition. I am saying this here to colleagues from the National Front. They can express themselves freely in the press and in the media, they are not imprisoned for it. It is our duty to call for the release of Mr Navalny.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, thousands of people took to the streets of Russia over the past days. Alarmed, the government detained an estimated 1 400 people across Russia. It is especially remarkable that more than one-in-six of these protestors were aged under 21. We are seeing a new generation of protestors unfolding under Vladimir Putin’s rule. In its attempt to repress and discredit any kind of opposition, in the past few years the Russian regime has employed various means, most prominently the control of traditional media. Alexei Navalny, leader of the Anti-Corruption Foundation, for example, was excluded from any kind of traditional media. Instead, Navalny found his audience on the internet, among those who have few memories of their country before Putin. This new culture of information consumption is now the main challenge to the regime, representing an alternative to the propaganda. We should embrace this movement, as accessibility of information is a staple of any democracy.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on Sunday, 26 March 2017, over 60 000 Russians gathered in over 80 cities across Russia to protest against corruption. It was the largest anti-governmental demonstration in the last five years. Russian citizens took to the streets despite, in many cases, not having received the requested authorisation for demonstrations. Still, the protests remained peaceful and non-violent. For this reason we consider the measures taken by the Russian authorities to be a disproportionate reaction.  The freedoms of expression, association, and peaceful assembly are fundamental rights guaranteed to the Russian citizens by the Russian Constitution. Peaceful protesters were detained and sentenced on a large scale.  These events raise strong doubts about the state of these fundamental rights in the Russian Federation. The response by the authorities to peaceful demonstrations was disproportionate and punitive. We were particularly alarmed by the indiscriminate actions of the authorities against young students and school pupils.  State authorities have a particular responsibility when dealing with young people and minors, a responsibility to always protect them against any physical and mental trauma. Journalists too were arrested while covering the events and subsequently released. Any actions against reporters who are simply doing their job represent a violation of freedom of the media, an incursion into the public’s right to know, and a clear breach of Russia’s international commitments. Overall, evidence shows that these kind of measures against journalists have a negative effect on free speech in the country.  Opposition leader and founder of the Anticorruption Foundation, Alexei Navalny, was also detained and sentenced to prison, alongside many other peaceful demonstrators. We believe that the Russian authorities have a responsibility to safeguard the fundamental rights of all their citizens, particularly in view of the presidential elections next year.  All political actors in the country have the right to play by the same rules on a level playing field. The European Union has made its position very clear with regard to these developments. We issued a statement on the events the same evening. The statement called on the Russian Federation to abide fully by the international commitments it has undertaken, including in the Council of Europe and the OSCE, to uphold the fundamental rights and to release immediately the detained peaceful demonstrators. We also expressed the same concerns during the OSCE Permanent Council on 30 March.  The European Union will continue to raise them, as necessary, with the Russian authorities.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place after the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: written. - The previous resolution on human rights violations in Russia dates from barely four months ago. Then and now, the N-VA delegation voted "in favor" with conviction. We support political and prisoners of conscience, persecuted journalists and human rights defenders in Russia and the occupied territories such as Crimea. Free speech is officially a constitutional right in Russia. However, as soon as you gain followers and thus become dangerous in the eyes of the regime, the law ends abruptly. Then you become the target of intimidation and persecution. Alexei Navalny, Boris Nemtsov, Denis Voronenkov, Nikolai Gorochov, Vladimir Kara-Murza, Alexander Litvinenko ... they are the known victims of a regime that tolerates less and less free speech, freedom of the press or opposition. The mass arrests during the March 26 demonstrations are disturbing. The EU must continue to send a message to the Kremlin with one voice that respect for human rights and international agreements is a prerequisite for becoming a reliable partner again.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Belarus (2017/2647 (RSP)).

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: author.- Ladies and gentlemen!Belarus is a strange country - Russia is over there, and the West has not yet begun.But both the West and Russia were there.Aleksandr Lukashenka is a strange dictator: one time he wants to build a common state with Russia, another time he wants to get closer to the European Union.Today, Aleksandr Lukashenka is at a stage far from the European Union, as he introduced an idiotic tax on unemployment and Belarusians are protesting against this tax.In Belarus, civil society is born and we must protect it, because it is better if there is the European Union in Belarus, there is the West of Europe than Asia than Russia, because it is better for us to have a friendly Belarus.Therefore, let us protect those demonstrators who are now imprisoned by Lukashenka.Hence the motion for this resolution.Thank you very much and I encourage you to support her.

name: Soraya Post
text: author. – Mr President, for some time we saw a thaw in Lukashenko’s Belarus. Political prisoners were released, it was easier to protest, and the EU scrapped sanctions and started cooperation. This changed with the new so-called ‘social parasite tax’. Anyone who works less than 183 days a year is sentenced to forced labour or fined EUR 240. That is two-thirds of the average monthly salary. The law also applies to stay-at-home mothers with children in preschool. Protests were met with mass detentions. The authorities must immediately release all peaceful protesters and journalists. If not, the EU must sanction the responsible officials. Alexander Lukashenko: let Belarus thaw again. Let us continue on the good path of cooperation, instead of speaking the language of sanctions.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: author.- After the events of the last few weeks in Belarus, our efforts as Europeans to build and improve relations with this country can only be described by the old ingenious phrase of one former Russian prime minister: "we wanted better, but came out as always".By lifting some of the sanctions, we hoped that President Lukashenko's regime in Belarus would at least partially respect human rights and freedoms.I remind you that the regime of President Lukashenko is not just a threat to the security of Belarusian citizens.In just two years' time, Europe will be in the slightest danger of a potentially unsafe nuclear power plant being built unsafe just 20 kilometers from the European Union's external border.I cannot understand why our major groups are avoiding this topic.Why, together with the Commission, is it avoiding to send a clear message to Belarus that Russia's ambitions to build potential nuclear bombs on the European Union's border are unacceptable to us?

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I would like to inform you that we are unfortunately delayed.Therefore, I would like to once again call for observance of time discipline and would like to inform you that, unfortunately, I will not be able to speak under the blue card procedure.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: author. - Mr. President, yes, human rights are violated in Belarus. Yes, there is repression, especially against those who demonstrate against an unfair measure. Yes, it is the only country in Europe that practices the death penalty. Yes, we must support the UN special rapporteur. But other rights are violated there, in particular those of migrants. They are mainly Chechens, Tajiks, Georgians or nationals of countries where this Parliament denounces the situation. These migrants seek to join the European Union to seek asylum. They are most often returned to Belarus, at the risk of being sent back to their country, where it is known what they risk, given that country’s good relations with Russia. Worse, the Union is currently negotiating a mobility partnership including, of course, a readmission agreement. I therefore regret that our proposals in this area were not accepted. It is not possible to keep only those human rights violations that work for each other and to ignore the risks that political opponents of Mr. Lukashenko's friends run. How does the Commission intend to uphold the right of asylum in this country? Human rights are not of variable geometry, they are too often forgotten within European institutions.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: author. – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, the one-year-old Council conclusions on lifting the EU sanctions was a decision taken on the basis of our goodwill and expectations. Have there been any positive steps by Lukashenko in reciprocity since then? I find none: elections in September were rigged, not a single political prisoner has been rehabilitated, the UN special rapporteur has been continuously ignored, the death penalty has never abolished, and they continue to execute people. The nuclear power plant in Ostrovets keeps growing, in violation of safety standards, nearly 50 kilometres away from an EU capital – Vilnius. As we speak, around 20 people remain in custody and may become new political prisoners. This is how dictators reciprocate. Colleagues, it is regrettable to see EU policy on Belarus looking like a self-repeating failure. This is so because some are attempting to curry favour with Lukashenko.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski
text: author. - There is no doubt that the situation in Belarus is getting worse. Unfortunately. But we must remember that Belarus is not Portugal - it is where it is, and Russia remains its most important partner. We hope that this effort of the last two years will not be wasted. Let me remind you: Belarus is no longer a country with political prisoners, efforts have been made to promote phytosanitary control, air protection, the Bologna system and its implementation. I was not in favor of this resolution, but I was in favor of the debate. We must take into account the fact that the deteriorating situation in Belarus is not the result of politicians' actions, but the grassroots opposition of society to the deteriorating economic and economic situation, but also political. Unfortunately, in the current situation, mainly politicians are the recipients of negative, inadequate reactions from the authorities themselves. Lebiedźka, Rymaszewski, and Statkiewicz are subjected to various repressions, primarily for being there. And it worries. Today, the European Parliament adopts a resolution in which it is not yet inclined to impose or return to sanctions against Belarus, but warns the Belarusian authorities that the path taken in March and the inadequate repression of the opposition against society may also end in a resolution and back to sanctions. Nobody in this House probably wants that, but this voice of the European Parliament today is extremely important because it is a warning.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: for the PPE Group. - Mr President, as my predecessor said, the situation in Belarus has deteriorated greatly. Just as the suppression of media independence and opposition has been growing in recent days, so has the performance of the economy declining. The decline in gross domestic product is almost four percent, inflation is rising sharply and public debt is growing every day. These unfavorable economic conditions drove thousands of citizens to the streets across Belarus at the end of March, and during peaceful demonstrations, these people expressed their disapproval and dissatisfaction with what was happening in the country. Unfortunately, the regime responded with great repression. Of the hundreds arrested, I would like to remind you that among them are members of the opposition Christian Democratic and civic parties. They are arrested for participating in a peaceful demonstration. Pavel Sevjaryněc was detained for ten days and fined, Vitali Rymaševský was detained and fined a thousand euros for participating in a peaceful demonstration, Anatol Ljabedzka was detained and also fined. I think that our resolution should make it clear that we will monitor the situation and hold the Belarusian regime accountable.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: on behalf of the S&D Group.- Mister President!Belarus is a troubled country.There are few areas in Europe where people have suffered more terrible things.Yet they have never given up their will for freedom and the pursuit of justice.That is why we must not leave people alone these days, and even supposed stability criteria must not prevent us from doing so.This Parliament resolution is a signal to the people of Belarus, a sign of solidarity and respect for the courage of the Belarusian people, and it is a clear warning to the government in Minsk not to continue this risky course of intimidation and deprivation of liberty and finallyAllow reforms.Stability can only be achieved if the rule of law, democracy and human rights apply.

name: Marek Jurek
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Mr Chairman!Our main goal in Eastern Europe must remain unchanged, that is, to consolidate the independence of the states that emerged after the collapse of the Soviet Union.So, first of all, we must support in Belarus the development of national identity and language rights, the revival of Christian life and the freedom of the Church, the development of public opinion and civic activity, openness to the West and independence, at least elements of the independence of Belarusian foreign policy.Today we can see that perhaps the upheavals we are witnessing are a sign that Belarus is entering a time of accelerated political change.Under these conditions, we should remember one thing, that the first of all social freedoms is the independence of the homeland, and this should determine our attitude towards the authorities and towards the opposition and social circles.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, well, it looks like the honeymoon is over and the first signs of a possible Minsk Spring are also over. Well, sometimes less is more, so I will be very brief.  Conditionality has to apply. We have lifted sanctions, we have provided concessions, and we expected changes. Those did not arrive. There is a crackdown, so we must reintroduce sanctions, and this time they have to be harder. Once again, once we see concrete changes and reforms we can add, but at the moment there is no other action than to take a very hard and tough stand.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Mr President, I absolutely agree with Mr Kosma Złotowski, and other authors, that the reason is the unfortunate bill condemning the so-called social parasites. Therefore, I am shocked that the draft resolution condemns the actions of police, which are quite normal. In every country, the police put protestors into jail sometimes. It is not our, or Mr Lukashenko’s, right to decide whether the police actions were exaggerated or not. Instead, the resolution should condemn the bill, and so I move the oral amendment that we should ask Mr Lukashenko to withdraw his bill. This pressure from the European Parliament would give him an excuse to withdraw this really unfortunate bill.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, in recent years, the European Union has taken a series of responses to Belarus.The response of President Lukashenko's regime has been a new repression, a new wave of repression, including the introduction of a subsistence tax, which has affected about 470,000 Belarusians this year.In response, an unprecedented number of people took to the streets, many of whom were arbitrarily arrested, fined and detained.These include Pavel Sevjaryněc, Vitali Rymaševský and Anatol Ljabedzka.I call on the Belarussian Government to release these demonstrators, journalists, civic activists and political prisoners.The Belarusian regime's willingness to accept the concept of human rights and civil society clearly does not exist, and the citizens of Belarus do not deserve that.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Parliament’s Rules of Procedure give the possibility to react to urgent cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. The initial idea was to express Parliament’s concern about the detention of some activists during and before the March demonstration in Belarus. However, we can see in the resolution that there are issues that cannot be termed very urgent. For example, the issue of the nuclear power plant in Astravets, the demand for the abolition of the death penalty, the recommendation to change tax legislation, the issue about studying in the EU and speeding up the visa and scholarship application process, electoral reform and other issues which cannot be described as urgent. I would like to remind you that four months ago, a non-urgent resolution with the same title on the situation in Belarus, in which the same issues were mentioned, was adopted. I urge you in the future not to create a spam effect, but concentrate more on urgent topics and do not reduce the power of urgent resolutions.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! We are all disappointed with the information that comes to us from Belarus. To push through this bill on free-rides, contrary to common sense, contrary to labor rights, blocking the media, blocking the activities of NGOs and political parties, rigging elections and simulating actions towards their democratization, and finally the brutal suppression of peaceful protests that have taken place recently, must meet opposition from this House. After all, all this happens after the European Union - with the hands of Parliament, and therefore also with our hands - has raised loans for Belarus. She provided financial support herself, lifted political and economic sanctions, because we wanted to see Belarus as a serious partner who keeps agreements. Trust and mutual respect are the basis of cooperation and if our partner says one thing but does the other, then plans and actions must be adjusted. In this situation, I would like to ask the European Commission whether the terms of the loans and financial guarantees granted to Belarus include the possibility of their suspension in the event of non-fulfillment of obligations in the area of ​​civil rights and the development of democracy?

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, protecting human rights activists from reprisal is a priority for the EU and indeed my own country, Ireland. It is imperative that the Belarusian authorities release and drop all judicial charges against peaceful protesters, journalists, human rights defenders, civil society activists and opposition members who have been detained in connection with the current wave of demonstrations. I welcome the call for this in the resolution. We should not allow ourselves to be mollified by piecemeal concessions when gross human rights violations remain. The political will for liberalisation shown by the Belarusian Government is incompatible with their use of capital punishment and renders them undeserving of EU rapprochement. I welcome this resolution by the Parliament and hope the Belarusian Government will act immediately to address the concerns that have been outlined in this resolution, particularly the call for electoral reform, and for Belarus to join the moratorium on the death penalty.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the right to protest, to express dissent and disagreement with the status quo, is important for modern democratic societies. It is worrying, therefore, to witness the on-going crackdown on civil society in many countries including, sadly, some Member States such as Hungary. But beyond our borders, in Russia and Belarus, young people are even more fed up with corrupt, dysfunctional and undemocratic governments. It is very worrying to see brave young activists, poets, journalists and human rights defenders being arrested and harassed. We must always speak out for freedom of expression. In that respect, I am pleased to support the Belarus Free Theatre, which continues to expose both their own country and Russia’s abuse of human rights. Our resolution calls for more support for educational exchange programmes and scholarships. It is only through people to people contact and investing in young people and their opportunities, that a vibrant civil society can be built.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: - If I hear it like that, calling President Lukashenko a dictator is actually a compliment: he is a despot, he is a tyrant. Just listen to what this stepfather of the Belarusian nation said about the work of some journalists. I quote: "If one of those journalists or politicians in my country would speak like that, then I would tear out his tongue with my own hands." This is what typifies this tyrant. For years he was only concerned with his personality cult and his own power. He has narrowed the political playing field, crippled civil society and pushed aside anyone who could offer a political alternative. A political scientist sums it up this way: “You don't have to understand who is guilty or innocent in Belarus. There are no laws and no courts. Lukashenko itself is the law and the court. He judges, but his decisions turn out to be wrong. Ultimately, there is no fear and no conscience. Lukashenko himself is the personification of fear and lack of conscience. ” We must not be indifferent. The EU must continue to give full support to the democratic forces, the defenders of human rights and fundamental freedoms in Belarus - Europe's last dictatorship.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Belarus continues to be the antipode of the fundamental approaches that govern the European Union, such as, among others, freedom of expression of citizens, respect for human rights, freedom of the media.Lukashenko presides over Belarus from a pseudo-dictatorial position, and let us not forget that in that country the death penalty is in place and there are dozens of political prisoners in its jails.For all these reasons, the European Union must be firm and forceful;forceful before this Belarusian government that is a satellite of Putin's Russian government.That is why the resolution is directed against the repression experienced by Belarusian citizens and also towards the release of political prisoners, and it will have the full support of my group - the People's Group - in this Parliament.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Mr President, over the past two years Belarus has indeed taken a step towards respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. These efforts, which have been rewarded by the European Union, must be maintained and stepped up. The Union must encourage leaders to get back on track. Recent events in Belarus are not acceptable. The arrests and the resulting violence must be strongly condemned; they have no place in a democracy. The demands and claims of the population must be listened to and heard. Parliament must firmly condemn any act contrary to the principle of respect for fundamental freedoms. We must call on Belarus to talk to its people and resolve these conflicts democratically. It is necessary to underline the efforts made by Belarus so far and to persuade it not to compromise everything. The Union will be able to support Belarus only if it protects its citizens and their rights. Mr Lukashenko must hear us and, if not, the Union will have to consider sanctions.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Belarus debate in the European Union continues to be driven by a policy of critical engagement. The most recent events in the lead-up to Freedom Day in Belarus on 25 March confirmed the need to maintain a critical approach in our bilateral relations. In reaction, we issued a statement pointing out that, despite the international community’s calls for restraint, the response by the security services, including preventive arrests beforehand and the detention of a large number of peaceful protesters on 25 March, itself were indiscriminate and inappropriate. We further noted that such limitations to the freedom of expression and assembly are in contradiction with Belarus’ stated policy of democratisation, as well as its international commitments. We called for the immediate release of all recently detained peaceful citizens. Belarus has taken a number of positive steps in recent years. These include the pro-active participation of Belarus in the Eastern Partnership and in the interim phase on modernisation issues; the resumption of the EU-Belarus Human Rights Dialogue; the start of negotiations on visa facilitation, readmission agreements and a mobility partnership; the active pursuit of cooperation in the harmonisation of digital markets; and the signature of a cooperation agreement on an early warning mechanism in the energy sector. Belarus has also played an increasingly constructive role in the region, notably with regard to the conflict in eastern Ukraine. After careful consideration, and with the support of Member States, including the local heads of mission in Minsk, and following the discussion in the political and security committee, it was decided to proceed with an EU-Belarus Coordination Group meeting on 3 and 4 April, understanding that this was an opportunity to pass strong and unambiguous messages to Belarussian interlocutors at an appropriate level. A specific session of the meeting was dedicated to human rights and political freedoms. This is exactly what we mean by critical engagement. Formats, such as the Coordination Group and the Annual Human Rights Dialogue, allow us to reiterate our commitment to a stable, democratic and prosperous future for Belarus for the benefit of its people. A range of subjects are of particularly importance to civil society were discussed at the meeting, including mobility, people-to-people contacts, trade, education and social security. The European Union also raised issues related to the registration of political parties, as well as the reinstatement of the civil and political rights of former political prisoners. In addition, separate meetings took place with Belarussian human rights defenders, civil society representatives and members of political opposition movements. The European Union will also raise these issues at the next Human Rights Dialogue, which is scheduled to take place before summer. As stated in the Council conclusions of 15 February 2016, the European Union is open to the further development of EU-Belarus relations and to enhancing political relations and sectoral cooperation in the appropriate context. At the same time, tangible steps taken by Belarus to respect universal fundamental freedoms, the rule of law and human rights will remain key for the shaping of the EU’s future policy towards Belarus. We take a note of today’s resolution on Belarus and share the concerns expressed. We will continue to closely observe Belarus’ response, with regard to freedom of speech, assembly and association, as we take our policy forward.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place after the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing.- Although our concepts of democracy and its good functioning may be different, I think we agree that the Belarussian regime does not meet the minimum requirements.Therefore, I do not think we should be surprised when, after a period that is perhaps milder and allows for rapprochement, this system has once again shown its true face.I think that change must start with the reform of the electoral system, the people of Belarus must say that they want to live in a society based on a different foundation.To do this, the country must move towards real democratic functioning, and the European Union can do no more than make cooperation conditional on respect for the rules of the democratic electoral rules before next year's elections.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE)
text: in writing. - On March 25, in Minsk, Belarusian anti-riot forces violently repressed the march that the opposition organizes annually, beating people, preventing journalists from doing their jobs and detaining around 700 protesters. The march aimed to protest the "law against social parasites" which created a special tax of 220 euros for those who work less than six months during the year and contribute less to state funding. The promoters of this peaceful march wanted it to coincide with Freedom Day, the unofficial date for the celebration of the first People's Republic of Belarus in 1918. But "freedom" is not a word dear to President Lukashenko, who has governed with an iron fist since 1994, possessing a long history of repression of peaceful demonstrations, political arrests and the shameful title of still being the only country in Europe to apply the death penalty! That same day, we celebrated the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome and reaffirmed our commitment to the values ​​of the founding fathers. It is in the name of these values ​​that we need to review the patterns of our relationship with Belarus and make it subject to respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law.

name: Kati Piri (S&D)
text: written. - Not being able to find work, but being fined for "working too little". It is the current situation in Belarus, where residents who spend less than 183 days per year at work receive a tax of EUR 234.00. The so-called "social parasite tax". This has resulted in massive protests in the country in recent weeks, with hundreds of people arrested. The measure and the arrests are seen as the straw that makes the bucket overflow. Belarus, once described by Condoleezza Rice as the "last and only dictatorship in Europe," is known for its flawed democracy and poor human rights conditions. In doing so, President Alexander Lukashenko will crack down on any form of protest. The levy is an arbitrary, bitter and morally questionable measure. In addition, coupled with the violent police action plus the lack of "freedom of association", Belarus is also violating international human rights. As the European Parliament, we must strongly condemn such actions and remind the country of its obligations.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. - Since the independence of the Republic of Belarus in 1991, citizens have not managed to build a full democracy in their country. The state has been ruled authoritarian since 1994 by Alexander Lukashenka. Belarusians, like other European nations, want to work, develop and become rich. The country is closely linked economically and politically with Russia, which is why it has indirectly been a victim of the economic difficulties currently experienced by its eastern neighbor. The protests that took place in many cities in Belarus were caused by the bad economic situation of the country and the tax imposed on unemployed people. A protest is a form of dialogue and expression of social discontent to which every nation is entitled. The information coming from Belarus about demonstrators detained by the police and arrested or fined are alarming. As reported by the non-governmental human rights organization Viasna, the total number of people subjected to various forms of repression as a result of a series of protests in March 2017 exceeds 900. The efforts of the Belarusian opposition to build a full democracy and a European direction of development should be supported. At the same time, the unstable political situation in the eastern region and the resulting threats must not be forgotten. Belarus should be supported in its pursuit of political independence and peacefully built democracy. Democracy built in a way that does not threaten Belarusian statehood and sovereignty.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on seven resolutions on Bangladesh, including child marriage (2017/2648 (RSP)).

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have a cooperation and partnership agreement on development with Bangladesh, and as the European Union we must have the courage to tell our partners when there are problems. And in Bangladesh, alas, there are many problems. With today's resolution we want to highlight a particularly serious one. In Bangladesh, the rate of girls marrying by the age of 18 is 52%; child brides under the age of 15 are 18% of the total. It is evident that in most cases it is not a choice, and for this reason the United Nations considers it a violation of human rights, because it opens the door to abuses related to dowry, sexual harassment, rape and legitimacy corruption of minors. For this reason, while acknowledging the efforts undertaken by Bangladesh in recent years to improve the situation, we want to tell the government that this is not enough and we must move forward in a more decisive and convinced way. The 2017 Child Marriage Restrictions Act - and the loopholes it contains, which effectively legalize these exceptions - must be discarded and completely rewritten. We want to remind the government that the most precious treasure of a country is always represented by its youth. Yes, because it is youth that we are talking about today, dear colleagues, of girls. And it is the task of a government to protect this treasure, to allow it to be educated in full respect of their rights and to guarantee them a future and the possibility of being able to choose freely and free from any constraint the person with whom they want to spend their life. In this case, we can only do our duty as a European Union and tell Bangladesh that it is time to take real concrete steps forward. This law is not enough and cannot be enough.

name: Soraya Post
text: author. – Mr President, a 14-year-old girl was brought to the altar to be married to a man twice her age for a dowry, forever. Fifty-two percent of girls in Bangladesh are married when they are 18 years old, and 18% before their 15th birthday. The new law against child marriages allows for so many exceptions that it will most likely lead to more girls being raped or disfigured in acid attacks. In nearly all cases, these girls will not get an education and will live in isolation, poverty, economic dependence and servitude. These girls are children, not objects for sale in the adults’ marriage market. Today, we – as Parliament – have the chance to let these girls learn that not all adults in the world have abandoned them. We are concerned about these girls’ future. We, as a Parliament, have to act.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: author. – Mr President, just imagine that you were 13, 14 or 15 years old and had been raped, and then your parents and the courts decided that it would be in your best interests to get married to the rapist. That is what the new provisions of this Child Marriage Restraint Bill in Bangladesh allow for. This is horrendous and we have to speak out. I am glad that we have a sense of urgency now, because even though Bangladesh pledged at the Girl Summit of July 2014 to reduce the number of girls marrying between the ages of 15 and 18 by 2021, this new law allows for so many exceptions that it is really a step backward and not forward. It could lead to an escalation of dowry abuse, sexual harassment, rape, acid violence, legitimisation of statutory rape and allow parents to force their daughters to marry their rapists. I am glad that we are speaking out very clearly against that. Let me nevertheless also refer to something else where I think Bangladesh still needs to move ahead. It is almost four years since the Rana Plaza disaster in 2013, when a textile factory collapsed, killing more than 1 100 women and some men, with more than 2 500 people injured. Until now, the sustainability compact, which is supposed to improve the situation in the garment industry, labour rights and factory safety, has not been implemented as much as it should have been. So I ask the External Action Service and the Commission to follow up on that to make sure that human rights, children’s rights and girls’ rights are taken into account in Bangladesh.

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Mr President, today’s resolution is very useful in highlighting the problems of forced child marriage and acts of sexual violence against women in Bangladesh, which we all rightly condemn. We must, however, distinguish such concerns from a wider condemnation of cultural norms and morals in Bangladesh, with very different social traditions and economic imperatives to those of our own here in the European Union. I am also mindful of the fact that in the United Kingdom and in Spain, the legal age of consent for marriage is 16, with the permission of parents.  On a separate point, I note in paragraph 13 the reference to the Foreign Donations Regulation Act, calling for its amendment. Of course, we wish to see a vibrant and free civil society operating in Bangladesh, and should be concerned by any legislation that prohibits such development. However, there have been problems with some NGOs and charities operating as vehicles for the funding of jihadi terrorism organisations and we must support the Bangladeshi Government’s right to crack down on these practices. Bangladesh is a secular country and enjoys a PCA with the European Union, and we should help it in its democratic progress and its prosperity.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: author. - Mr President, Bangladesh has passed a legal reform that allows the marriage of minors in "certain circumstances", but these "certain circumstances" leave the door open to legalize a practice that is already very common. According to Unicef, Bangladesh has the world's second highest rate of child marriage and the highest in Asia. More than half of the girls - already mentioned here - are married before the age of eighteen and the number is very high before the age of fifteen. This legislative reform is a setback in terms of human rights, and especially in relation to the rights of women and girls. Let us not forget that child marriage is often a consequence of poverty and inequality, that is, it is fought with effective social policies, especially in education and health, including, of course, respect for health and rights. sexual and reproductive conditions of girls because, many times, unwanted pregnancies are what lead to child marriage. We must not forget either the serious situation that this country is experiencing with regard to workers' rights, social freedoms, freedom of expression and opinion. The data of arbitrary arrests, extortion and torture of trade unionists, opponents and human rights defenders are very common and very alarming. For this reason, the Commission should initiate an investigation as soon as possible on compliance with international conventions on human and labor rights. We cannot continue to offer a generalized system of preferences to a country in which human rights violations are becoming more serious every day, especially against women.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: author. – Mr President, child marriage is a violation of human rights. Children are simply not able to give their full consent, and there is enough evidence showing the serious psychological and physical impact of marrying as a child. Bangladesh knows this and has tried to reduce the number of child marriages, but taking away the minimum age and creating special conditions for children to marry is not a solution. There can be no special cases when it comes to violation of human rights.  Bangladesh already had one of the highest rates of child marriage in the world with the ban in place. The new law will simply encourage the practice to continue and even intensify the current situation. The Bangladeshi authorities must act now to ensure that this does not happen. The special circumstances that allow for child marriage must be clearly defined and very difficult to use. The penalties for breaking the law must be strong and upheld to deter child marriage from the outset. For cases where a girl becomes pregnant, other safe and legal alternatives to marriage must be available. The EU must be active and willing to support the Bangladeshi authorities to achieve this and, on a broader scale, to respect all of its human rights obligations.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: Author.- Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party, I would like to say that in Bangladesh, despite the progress made in many areas, human rights are still being suppressed in many ways.I am thinking in particular of children's weddings, especially for girls under the age of 18, and even under the age of fifteen.I am very surprised by the fact that a law was passed in Bangladesh in February this year, which de facto allows these practices to continue.This is despite the fact that the Bangladeshi government has recently committed itself to gradually reducing the proportion of these children's weddings.There is also a continuing suppression of children's rights, which has a negative impact on their psyche, education and their future lives.We can't tolerate that.We must call on the local government to change this law and to ban all children's weddings, without exception.

name: Csaba Sógor
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - President! We speak out against child marriage not only because it violates children's rights, because it is no longer an accepted social norm in today's European countries, although it is still a living practice in some communities today. On the one hand, we find it unacceptable because they pose a huge health risk to girls, who are often forced into marriage against their will. These children are neither physically nor mentally prepared for the tasks of childbirth and motherhood, but they are forced to do so in accordance with social customs. On the other hand, we think that the practice of child marriages should be stopped because they actually preserve poverty. The studies of a child entering into marriage are interrupted and dropping out of the education system is a barrier to social mobilization. Therefore, it would be important that in the developing countries of South Asia, where every second woman marries before the age of 18 and every sixth before the age of 15, there is a noticeable change in this area.

name: Arne Lietz
text: on behalf of the S&D Group.-  Mister President!The law passed in Bangladesh to restrict child marriage unfortunately still contains exceptional situations that allow child marriages.In Bangladesh, 52 percent of girls are currently married on their 18th birthday and 18 percent of girls on their 15th birthday.From the point of view of the European Parliament, the law could result in an increase in dowry-related violence, sexual harassment, rape and acid attacks and legitimize the rape of minors.The situation is thus even given that girls could be forced to even have to marry potential rapists.That is why I support our motion for a resolution calling on the government to change this law.The legal loopholes must be closed in order to ban all child marriages.

name: Jana Žitňanská
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, every year up to 15 million girls under the age of 18 are forced to marry many older partners. Every minute it represents 28 underage girls. One girl every two seconds. Bangladesh is one of the countries with one of the highest proportions of children's weddings in the world, and it is also the sad leader in Asia. More than half of girls undergo forced marriage before reaching the age of majority, and almost 20% are even under the age of 15. In this context, it is alarming that in Bangladesh, they have recently passed a law banning, on the one hand, the marriage of minors, even setting a minimum age for boys at 21, and, on the other hand, the so-called allows exceptions in justified cases. However, the text of the law does not specify a lower age limit for these exceptions, and there is also a real fear that the exceptions will be abused and thousands of girls will lose their childhood. So today, it seems that girls in Bangladesh are not protected from forced marriages by the law, but by their better education, because educated girls are better able to defend themselves and decide on their own lives.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, we only hear about Bangladesh when there is an accident in a textile plant that works for Western companies and dozens of unprotected workers die. But in Bangladesh, one of the poorest countries in the world, there are more things that deserve our attention, even if they do not affect our business interests. In more than half of marriages in Bangladesh, a country of 150 million people, the bride is a girl, a minor. Until a few months ago, the law expressly prohibited a girl under the age of eighteen from marrying. But they have just reformed it by introducing a gap of exceptionality to the norm. For what? So that girls who become pregnant can marry their future father, that is, her abuser. This was confirmed to me recently at the United Nations by the Minister for Women's and Children's Affairs, Mrs. Meher Afroz Chumki. There can be no exception that allows child marriage. Bangladeshi girls need legal protection and comprehensive sexual and reproductive education. The European Union has pledged new aid of almost 700 million under its Multi-Annual Indicative Program for Bangladesh. Mrs Mogherini, Mr Mimica, I ask you to be strict here. Freeze those funds immediately. Let's not finance a government that opens back doors to marriages with minors.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Bangladesh continues to be talked about when it comes to human rights violations on several fronts: freedom of association, early marriage, arbitrary arrests and abuse by law enforcement. Years have passed since the Rana Plaza tragedy, a tragedy that attracted the attention of world public opinion. But nevertheless, no change has really happened. It seems clear to us that there has been no real awareness on the part of the government on the need to make the necessary reforms. Indeed, it has gone from bad to worse: the minimum wage has not been increased since 2013, while the cost of living has increased significantly, forcing workers, trade unionists and journalists to go on strike and report the unacceptable living conditions to which they are subjected. In response, the government has decided to proceed with arrests and repressions and, as if that were not enough, has practically legalized child marriage. We absolutely must express our dissent. The European Commission must launch an investigation to highlight the breaches of the European Union's Generalized System of Preferences by the government of Bangladesh and act accordingly.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, is rud uafásach, mhífhéaráilte, sean-nósach é an nós ‘pósadh leanaí’. Faraor, tá sé forleathan timpeall an domhain, agus measann an ghluaiseacht idirnáisiúnta ‘Cailíní, ní Brídeoga’ go mbíonn ar suas le 71% de chailíní faoi ocht mbliana déag d’aois pósadh.  Níl seo féaráilte. Is í an Bhanglaidéis ceann de na tíre is measa. Tá sé i gcoinne an dlí. Ach cén mhaitheas an dlí nuair a thugann an rialtas isteach leasú a cheadaíonn eisceacht i gcásanna speisialta? Cad is cás speisialta ann? D’fhéadfadh gach cás a bheith ina chás speisialta.  Dá bhrí sin, caithfimid brú a chur ar údarás na Banglaidéise an lúb ar lár seo a athrú agus freisin, ba chóir dúinn cabhrú leo chun oideachas a chur ar fáil agus chun cosc a chur ar an gcultúr a ligeann don sean-nós uafásach de phósadh leanaí tarlú agus é a stopadh go deo.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the Government of Bangladesh has committed itself to concrete goals to combat the marriages of children and underage girls, a scourge that leaves terrible emotional physical consequences, destroys normal personality development and carries an increased risk of poverty, illiteracy and sexual and physical violence. Bangladesh has made some progress in this regard, despite continuing to be the country with the highest worldwide rate of this disregard for human rights. However, the recently passed child marriage restriction law, instead of being a decisive step in combating this drama, proves to be a perverse law that introduces exceptions in special cases or in the interests of the teenager, without elucidating the criteria that preside over those classifications and without establishing a minimum age for the marriages in question. Bangladesh is a country that benefits from the UN World Population Fund Program and UNICEF to accelerate the fight against child marriage, a program that has the European Union as one of the funders. The European Union must therefore make efforts to pressure the Bangladeshi authorities to revise the child marriage restriction law, otherwise we will see a step backwards in combating this practice, which is the cause of so much suffering.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I am obliged to you. I take the floor today in my capacity as Chairman of the Standing Committee, within the International Trade Committee, for South Asian Trade, and with Bangladesh I have had the unique ability to see at first hand the tremendous amount of improvement that has taken place using trade mechanisms for women’s empowerment in Bangladesh and in particular female-headed households.  What we see here today is, however, a tremendous regression from the progress that has been made. At the very moment in time at which a young female needs the support of her society and country, it seems that other obligations may be placed in the way and her best interests not necessarily taken into account.  So I say simply this to the Government of Bangladesh: as a Union we have worked with you, we have stood with you, we have been very proud to see the tremendous improvements that you have made, but please, listen to what this House is conveying to you today. These sorts of developments do not take us forward. They challenge our relationship and we do not want to move away from encouraging you to keep moving forward on women’s empowerment issues.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! I, too, would like to draw your attention to the dramatic situation of children in Bangladesh. Bangladesh has one of the highest child marriage rates in the world. Unfortunately, despite earlier declarations, in order to combat this negative phenomenon, at the end of February the Parliament of Bangladesh passed a law under which the marriages of minors could take place in special cases. However, the lack of a definition of these cases means that de facto the lack of a minimum age for marriage has been sanctioned. There are also legitimate concerns that the new law will be used, among other things, to force raped girls to marry their abuser in an ill-conceived saving of honor, further aggravating their trauma. Meanwhile, I expect the Bangladeshi government to focus on protecting the rights and welfare of children and fulfilling previous commitments on this subject.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would, of course, also very much like to condemn the forced marriages that are taking place in Bangladesh. I think it is important not only to condemn this factual situation, but also the leaky law as described here. Also the non-compliance with the international commitments made by Bangladesh. I think it's all reprehensible. But I also think that we should not be hypocrites, and at the same time we should say what happens if Muslim people come to European countries and have a wife with them who, for example, is under the age of 15 and consume marriage in Europe. . I think that we should also make it clear in this matter that such conduct is unacceptable in the European area, and that we should also condemn in this way the behavior that is taking place, and what we know about, in Europe. In this regard, we should send a clear message to the Member States of the European Union.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, according to the UN, Bangladesh still has the highest rate of child marriage in the world.The report found that 52% of girls in Bangladesh are married under the age of 15.Unfortunately, the recent 2017 law only prohibits marriages and in fact leaves room for children's marriages.I appreciate the resolution, but it is not enough.There is a need for the education of children and adolescents and obviously for a change in legislation.Commissioner, I believe that the Commission must use appropriate tools, together with other international institutions, Unicef, the UN, to change the current tragic situation in practice, because girls will be left with a fingerprint all their lives after being forced to marry their aggressors..

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I support the resolution I signed for a country, Bangladesh, where child labor in factories, mainly European and other multinational companies, is on the agenda. The UN considers child marriage to be a violation of human rights. In Bangladesh, at present, 18% of married girls are under 15 years old. Bangladesh has reportedly decided to take action to restrict the marriage of minors under the age of 15 until 2021. However, the law passed allows these marriages to take effect. That is why we consider this legislation unacceptable, because it will essentially allow rapists to marry raped underage girls.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Union has constantly and consistently called on the government of Bangladesh to guarantee respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law. This political outreach was a joint action with this Parliament. During two recent visits to Bangladesh, distinguished Members of the European Parliament called on the government to respect human rights, the rule of law, the democratic process, freedom of expression and fundamental labour rights. These visits received widespread local press coverage.  The European Union human rights strategy identifies the prevention of child marriage as a priority. The European Union regularly raises the issues of child marriage with the Bangladesh authorities, most recently during the EU-Bangladesh subgroup on good governance and human rights. In December last year in particular, the European Union raised concerns with regard to the Child Marriage Prevention Act, which keeps the marriageable age of girls at 18 but allows exceptions under specific circumstances.  Furthermore, the European Union has contributed EUR 6 million to the funding of the UNFPA-UNICEF and UNFPA global programme on child marriage, which also benefits the fight against child marriage in Bangladesh.  As regards the wider human rights situation in Bangladesh, at the EU-Bangladesh subgroup on good governance and human rights the EU raised concerns on extra-judicial killings and enforced disappearances, the death penalty, freedom of association and freedom of expression, the situation of minorities, violence against women, and fundamental labour rights.  At the EU-Bangladesh diplomatic consultation held in Brussels in February this year, while recognising progress made so far under the Sustainability Compact, the European Union underlined the need to address the shortcomings in compliance with freedom of association.  Human rights are also part of the partnership on development aid and cooperation set out in the Multiannual Indicative Programme for Bangladesh, which provides support to the sectors of nutrition, education and good governance for the period until 2020, for a total amount of EUR 690 million. Child marriages and other human rights issues will be further discussed at the EU-Bangladesh Joint Commission to be held in Brussels in the first half of this year.  The European Union stands ready to work together with the government of Bangladesh in addressing these issues.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- For years the European Union has been trying to cooperate with Bangladesh to put an end to a sad practice, that of marriage for minors.The latter are forced by their families to marry and there is no law expressly prohibiting it.The resulting psycho-physical damage is very serious and the EU cannot stand by while the future of millions of children is stolen.The Bangladeshi government must make marriages illegal for minors.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - At the plenary session in Strasbourg on 6 April, we addressed a joint motion for a resolution on Bangladesh, including child marriage. The European Union has a long-standing relationship with Bangladesh, including a partnership and development cooperation agreement. The promotion of human rights and democratic principles is one of the EU's fundamental principles not only in domestic but also in international politics. In recent months, however, according to independent observers, there have been human rights violations, enforced disappearances, repression of civil societies, attacks on political activists and torture. In addition, Bangladesh is still the country with the highest number of child marriages in the world. With this motion for a resolution, we call on the Bangladeshi Government to end child marriages, to condemn the continuing reprehensible acts against freedom of expression and to ensure an immediate end to all acts of violence, harassment, intimidation and censorship against journalists, bloggers and civil society.

name: Anthea McIntyre (ECR)
text: in writing. – I believe we must demand that the government of Bangladesh respect its international obligations on human rights, and not only with respect to child marriage, important though that is. The Bangladesh authorities must condemn acts of violence towards innocent citizens. They must commission an independent investigation into extrajudicial killings and bring those responsible to justice. I listened to a recording (in translation) of a serving Rapid Action Battalion (RAB) officer exposing crimes he and fellow officers are instructed, by the authorities, to carry out. He describes how RAB officers select and kill people. These extra-judicial killings are known as ‘crossfire’. Officers place a discharged weapon beside the body to fabricate evidence against the dead individual, claiming they opened fire on RAB officers and were therefore killed in self-defence. He reveals that RAB officers are instructed to capture, kill and dispose of the body without it being traceable. He concludes that the victims are mainly from the country’s opposition parties. The government is using the RAB in its crackdown on the main opposition parties which continue to demand free, fair and participatory national elections in Bangladesh following the flawed elections in 2014.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - Bangladesh is the fifth country in the world in the number of child marriages. 52% of girls marry before the age of eighteen, and 18% before the age of fifteen. In rural areas of the country, this ratio is even higher and even more frightening - 71% of girls are forced to marry and grow up before the age of eighteen. It is a sad realization that parents, at risk of severe poverty, have no other way to secure the future, sometimes the lives, of their own daughters than to marry them in their childhood and premature youth. Every minute around the world, 28 girls are left without a future due to child marriages, which brings with it huge physical, mental and emotional consequences. The government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh has pledged to adopt a national plan to completely eradicate child marriages by 2041, and last year passed the Child Marriage Restriction Act, which introduces stricter penalties for people who have children, but the law is full of shortcomings. , without specifying the “special conditions” that need to be met in order for a child marriage to be legally valid. Children have the right to a childhood, but in order to ensure a childhood for children, we must provide their parents with minimum standards for a dignified life so that they do not resort to such terrible moves. Eradicating poverty is a goal we must achieve.
