name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I was very happy to support this resolution, because the fight against roaming is a concrete, tangible thing that we can show the citizens of the nation states that the European Union can benefit their lives and do something good for them.And I am also pleased that we have finally adopted a bolder solution than the one originally proposed by the Commission, and that we have further reduced the ceilings for wholesale roaming charges.I would like to thank the rapporteur on this, who has made a significant contribution to lowering the ceilings for roaming charges every year.So the proposal is good, it is right, and that is why I was happy to support it.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, when the S&D Group called for an end to roaming charges almost six years ago, there was a lot of opposition from national governments, from the PPE Group in Parliament, and even from the Commission. Our perspective changed the situation and our longstanding priority will now finally become reality on 15 June.  Roaming charges are now a thing of the past. Europeans no longer face huge phone bills after travelling. They can use their phones abroad just like at home without paying extra. Instead of switching off their phone when crossing a border, people will now be able to call their friends at home, tweet from a conference, or check their emails at the airport. Under the leadership of our Group, Parliament defended the interest of citizens and small operators against big telecom companies, being able to push the data price cap down benefits consumers directly as the lower the cap, the more data they can use when travelling.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, when this issue of roaming charges came before the Parliament, mine was one of the very few voices and very few votes against it. There is a competitive market, and there was no obvious need for state intervention. By privileging one particular type of tariff – in other words, that of the person who travels a lot – we end up effectively requiring a subsidy from kids on estates who don’t travel in order to subsidise people like us who do a lot of travel. But that is not my point today. I lost the argument and I lost that vote. My point is that the reduction in international roaming charges is happening anyway, is happening globally, and has nothing to do with this legislation. It is being done by individual operators. We politicians are not as important as we think we are. There is this solipsistic fallacy where we assume that everything going on in the world is somehow the creation of laws and law-makers. A parting bit of advice as Britain comes towards the end of its time here, my friends: we are really not at the centre of affairs.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in the Middle Ages each feudal lord could block the road and start to take money from travellers for travelling on the road. We can see some feudal features in the mobile network market in the 21st century in the European Union. Important steps were taken by the Commission and Parliament to change the situation and abolish roaming charges in the EU, but the EU mobile network market remains fragmented. After the abolition of roaming charges, the next challenge could be that some big companies are tempted to take more money for a wholesale roaming charge. If we do not limit their wishes, this could lead to an increase in charges to consumers. The Commission and Parliament propose to establish the maximum level of wholesale roaming charges telecom operators can charge each other for calls, text messages and data from 15 June this year, and I am in favour of this decision.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I am very pleased that now we are finally there in our seven-year battle to introduce ‘Roam like at home’ for our citizens, and I would like to thank all MEPs who voted in favour today: 547 in favour, 27 against, 50 abstaining. Indeed, I would take issue with what my good friend Mr Hannan said from the United Kingdom. The European Parliament did play a huge part. If the markets had their way, the prices would be much higher because they would collaborate with one another. When the Commission made its proposals, the wholesale prices were much higher, and it was only the good work of those of us who were actually involved – and if Mr Hannan and his colleagues had got more involved they would know what was going on – that reduced, first of all, the roaming charges over a period of years, and now finally this piece in the jigsaw: the wholesale charges and we can have ‘Roam like at home’. Otherwise, the prices would be sky high, as Mr Hannan would like us to have.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: –  Mr President, after years of negotiations, after the informal agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council in the last days of February this year, today we have all, together, demonstrated our strong commitment to visa-free travel to Ukrainian citizens. Very soon, Ukrainian citizens will be able to travel in the EU for 90 days without having a visa. The full importance of today’s vote cannot be underestimated. By granting Ukrainians the freedom to travel through the EU we have demonstrated that the unprecedented reforms undertaken by the Ukrainian Government are bearing tangible fruit, but above all, we are pointing out that we refuse to follow the path of closeness, nationalism, populism, that so many politicians are suggesting today. Today we have embraced openness and we should be proud of it. I now call for the EU Member States to implement today’s vote as soon as possible.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: - Only three years have passed since that day, the events of Maidan, and we have a great example when a country that has told itself that it will change, that it wants to see its future in Europe, has started to make progress.Yes, it took time because there was a lot of work to be done - 72 criteria on which Ukraine had to make progress.We worked together, we went together, progress was made.I congratulate the European Union and Ukraine on the fact that we have made great progress together.This reaffirms that the European Union remains open to those countries that are on the path to progress.The good news for Ukrainian citizens: they will not be discriminated against, they will be able to travel freely to the European Union, just as European citizens will be able to travel to Ukraine.I hope we learn more about each other, there will be no myths, no misinformation and together we will move towards our common future.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the dialogue with Ukraine on the abolition of visas has been launched since 2008. Since then, the Commission has made numerous reports of progress, mainly after the November 2013 demonstrations on the Maidan and after the 2014 elections. for Ukraine throughout this period and, we must tell the truth, there was no consensus in the European Parliament to condemn Russian aggression against Ukraine and, implicitly, Crimea. He came a little later and with sanctions. People died during this time; more than 9,000 people died between 2013 and 2014 in Donetsk and Luhansk alone. That is why it is vital to help them. That is why we need to monitor what is happening with the money we give to Ukraine, the fight against corruption, the rule of law and the efforts of Ukraine, and we will make them happy without visas.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I am very pleased that a resolution has passed today that clearly states that visa-free travel will be established between the European Union and Ukraine. It is the culmination of several years of process. Two years ago, Ukraine fulfilled the conditions for the introduction of visa-free travel. For me, it is not just about Ukrainian citizens being able to travel around the European Union without a visa for 90 days, but this decision today is of great symbolic significance. We clearly tell the Ukrainians that we count on them to be our partners, and I hope that today's decision will further strengthen the feeling of most Ukrainians that they want to be a major partner towards the European Union and that the European Union as a set of democratic partners is the main partner. States, not Russia, which - as we all know - is carrying out aggression in eastern Ukraine. So the geopolitical level, the symbolic gesture, is perhaps even more important than the fact that Ukrainians themselves will be able to travel around the European Union in this way. I am glad that with this gesture we are strengthening the ties between the European Union and Ukraine.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, European solidarity must increase.This can be solved through education and involvement.I am glad that I was able to vote on such a report, this resolution on the European Solidarity Corps, but I drew attention to the debate that we need to have precise implementing rules from the Commission, budgets, to have new budgets, we do not have toit is taken from other forms of youth support.Of course, the impact must also be monitored, calculated and this new project must be correlated with other youth support projects for involvement not only in solidarity, but also in daily work.We need to provide them with jobs after volunteering.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: –  Mr President, along with other members of my group I voted against the committee’s report on the adequacy of protection afforded by the EU/US Privacy Shield in favour of supporting the alternative text tabled by the EPP and the ECR. The committee report contains very critical statements that I believe could potentially harm businesses that rely on the Privacy Shield to transfer data across the Atlantic securely and efficiently.  This criticism comes before the upcoming comprehensive annual review which is envisaged in the Privacy Shield framework, which ensures that the European Commission and data protection authorities can monitor the functioning of the system and keep it up to date, and so the claims in the report are therefore premature. The EPP/ECR text better acknowledges this upcoming inclusive review and is more balanced in its critique of the Safe Harbour system which has not changed in the time since the EPP resolution of May 2016, which welcomed the substantial improvements in the Privacy Shield compared with Safe Harbour. This allows the comprehensive review to take place and assess the findings afterwards.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D).
text: –  Mr President, in fact for many years the European Parliament has been at the forefront of efforts to protect citizens from the abuse of their personal data, so I was therefore very pleased to vote for this important resolution on improving the EU/US Privacy Shield, and I do not agree that it is a burden on business. This is not just a matter of human rights, it is also a matter of consumer confidence, and there are very real concerns about the scope of the protection within this agreement. It is better than the US Safe Harbour protections, but there are concerns about the use of data through automatic decision-making, and there are concerns about the remedies that will be available to EU citizens if there is a problem. So it is absolutely right that Parliament has taken a firm stand here. I also think that the Commission should have allowed Parliament to scrutinise this in a better way, because the use of the Implementing Act procedure in this particular instance has not worked out to our advantage. But overall I am extremely pleased with this resolution, and it enables us to take forward our work in this area.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we are here to bring to the attention of the European institutions today - indeed for the umpteenth time - this phenomenon, which has become a phenomenon, sadly known as the "Land of the fires ", which is actually an environmental and health emergency in which more than two and a half million European citizens are forced to live in an area included in 57 municipalities in the provinces of Naples and Caserta, in Southern Italy. More than 6,000 sites have been identified in those parts to date - in reality this figure is still a provisional figure, because searches are still ongoing - where toxic waste, 10 million tons of toxic waste and 10 million tons of toxic waste have been illegally spilled or burned. hazardous, including both urban and industrial waste, thus transforming that land into one of the most polluted areas in the entire European Union. The epidemiological picture of the resident population in those parts shows excesses of mortality and hospitalization for all the diseases that can be traced back to the release or combustion of toxic waste. Unfortunately, mortality for all types of cancer is 20% higher than the national average, in absolute contrast to the trends because, while in Italy these trends are descending, in the Land of Fires there is an increase in mortality for all types of cancer. Male infertility is 17% higher than the national average. The health picture of children is really scary, because there is an excess of hospitalizations for all cancers, especially in the first year of age, and there is an excess of tumors, especially of the central nervous system in the age group that it goes between zero and 14 years. Despite this, ostracism continues by all those who leverage the difficulty of establishing a scientific connection between this exposure to industrial poisons and the cancer. There are people who even go so far as to deny this causal link. Yet there is no family that has not had a tragic experience, a dramatic experience of cancer, of one or more cancers, among their loved ones. In the last twenty days, for example, in the last twenty days alone, eight other children have died from cancer. Now the inhabitants of that area are afraid of drinking the water that flows from their taps, they are afraid of eating vegetables, the vegetables they produce on their land. And, as if that were not enough, the local economies, the agri-food productions have suffered a devastating effect due to the negative publicity which, of course, has weakened the local economies, which were already weak in themselves. We have all received the report of the Italian permanent representation, which gives the usual reassuring message, a reassuring message that illustrates the actions implemented both by the Italian government and by the regional government of the Campania Region, and which seems to be finally addressed, this program, to definitively resolve this situation. The point is that for years, for over 20 years, these people have listened to reassuring messages and things have never changed. To this day there are still these fires, these fires are still there, and the waste is going to be burned right now. Therefore we are here today to denounce the uselessness and ineffectiveness of all the solutions that have been adopted by the Italian government and by the regional government of the Campania Region, because the complaints of dozens in parliamentary committees, for example, were useless. or the dozens of journalistic inquiries, the complaints of citizens' associations and above all the death toll in the cemeteries of those poisoned lands. Commissioner, this is the largest mass poisoning in any of the countries of our European Union, and we believe that the European institutions have a duty to intervene. Therefore we want to know if this Union intends to restore hope to these citizens, who are also their European citizens, and if this Union intends to give the right priority to respect for the right to health for European citizens and therefore also for the citizens of the Earthof the fires.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, Mr Pedicini, let me start first of all by saying that the Commission has been very deeply concerned for many years about the environmental situation from which the region of Campania is suffering due to the illegal treatment and mismanagement of waste, and of course about the impact on public health. The latest public health report issued by the Istituto Superiore di Sanità, which links the abnormally high cancer rate in some parts of Campania with the illegal treatment of waste, has been brought to our attention.  Given the systematic shortcomings in waste management in Campania underpinned by organised crime, the Commission has made full use of its powers over the past decade to address the situation. Already in 2007 the Commission initiated infringement procedures against Italy for a lack of adequate disposal facilities for waste in Campania, and this led in 2010 to Italy being condemned by the European Court of Justice. Then again in 2015 the court condemned Italy to pay a heavy fine consisting of a lump sum of EUR 20 million plus EUR 120 000 every day due to insufficient follow-up measures.  One year earlier, in 2014, the Court of Justice had already imposed heavy fines on Italy for the existence of illegal disposal of waste, including hazardous waste, throughout practically all the Italian territory, including Campania. Also in 2014, the Commission suspended EU financial assistance corresponding to the financial period 2007-2013 in respect of waste management and disposal in Campania. We cannot grant EU money if there are no guarantees that it will be spent well. When we received adequate assurances, EU funding was again made available in the current programing period.  As regards enforcement by the Commission, there was nothing more that we could possibly do according to EU law. Now it is fair to say that the overall waste management situation in Campania has improved since the waste crisis of 2007 and following the government’s appointment of several waste emergency commissioners for the region. For instance, separate collection of waste in the region is steadily improving, as well as recycling. At the end of last year, Campania adopted a new regional waste management plan which is now being examined by the Commission services.  But challenges remain, and health problems caused by past practices are still making themselves felt. The health and the environmental issues in Campania have their roots in the existence of organised crime and an enforcement system which is not coping with it. Although the main responsibility for fighting organised crime rests with the Member States, the European Union has agreed to take action on a number of instruments in the field of enforcement of compliance.  To address the eco-mafia, in 2011 Europol created a platform for experts from law enforcement agencies, the EnviCrimeNet, dealing with environmental crime. Also to improve enforcement, the Commission will adopt later this year a communication setting out an action plan with practical actions for environmental compliance assurance. This will be aimed, amongst other issues, at helping Member States to combat waste crime and offences. In addition to the enforcement actions, the Commission has urged the Italian competent authorities to address land decontamination and rehabilitation as a matter of urgency. For the latter, EUR 72 million of EU structural funds have been made available under the current financial period, that is under the period 2014-2020.  Of course the specific health-related aspects are of huge concern and I know that the signatories of this major interpellation, including my colleague Pedicini, already met with my colleague Commissioner Andriukaitis here in Strasbourg few weeks ago. As you know, health policy is essentially a national competence but there may be scope for reinforcing dialogue with national authorities. I can assure you that my services will keep monitoring the situation in Campania. Solving the problems derived from the illegal treatment of waste in Campania is dependent on all relevant actors working effectively together.

name: Jiří Pospíšil
text: for the PPE Group. - Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the Commissioner's answer to this serious question, which concerns Campania and the huge pollution in the area. As I am often critical of the way in which the Commission's representatives speak here, I must now say that I personally agree with that answer. It must be said openly that, although this is an extremely serious fact, and as my colleagues rightly write here, the lives and health of many hundreds and thousands of Europeans living in the region are being harmed, so the primary responsibility for the situation and for resolving it must have Italy as such. Because if the situation that has arisen there, and this is clearly stated here, is the result of an illegal situation, it is the result of illegal waste management, then it is difficult for the European Union to solve this primarily. But I am very happy, and it is important here that the Commissioner said here that the European Union is ready to help, it is encouraging and positive for me, that it has been said here that there is money in the Structural Funds, because I think how I know the situation. for example from the Czech Republic, where we removed ecological burdens and it cost us hundreds and hundreds of millions of crowns, that without the support of European money it would be difficult to remove such a large ecological burden. So if the European Commission provided the regional government with money to repair such huge environmental damage, I would personally welcome and support such a situation for myself as an MEP. But the original thesis must be that Italy's primary willingness to create such landfills in the future must be punished, the perpetrators will be punished because it is a serious crime, and that the Italian government itself will want to spend money on remediation. Europe can add to that. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: Question "blue card".- Mr Pospíšil, the Commissioner too, earlier, repeated all the infringement procedures that have been imposed on Italy in relation to this issue.I ask you: according to you, the method of the infringement procedure itself, which is a form of tax that is paid directly by the same citizens who are already harassed from the point of view of health and lack of environmental protection, is a method thatdoes it work, or not?The same citizens who pay in terms of health then also pay in terms of taxes.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Colleague, I'm a lawyer.If there is a legitimate reason for a state to be affected by a ruling of the European Court of Justice, then unfortunately it simply has to be.The question is whether the law is violated or not.But I am also making it clear here that Italy is to be provided with assistance from the Structural Funds to deal with this environmental burden, because, in principle, large environmental burdens cannot be solved from national budgets.

name: Nicola Caputo
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since 2003, when it appeared for the first time in a Legambiente report on eco-mafias, the expression "Terra dei fuochi" has characterized and marked an entire area of ​​Campania which embraces various municipalities in the province of Caserta and Naples. I myself come from that rich and fertile land, which for centuries has been called "Land of work". "Terra dei fuochi" summarizes and emphasizes what took place in these areas between the nineties and the beginning of the new century: an irresponsible and uncontrolled spill of toxic substances, waste and waste of all kinds, which is often their incineration followed. A criminal and systematic pollution activity, which was able to count on a chain of negligence and omissions and on the tragic unpreparedness of the competent authorities to stem the phenomenon. I denounced it in this House during my first one-minute speech of this legislature. The impact of the Terra dei Fuochi has been devastating for the life and health of tens of thousands of people and for the economy of the entire Campania region. Since November there has been a new emergency in terms of mortality, especially of children. The data is similar to the years 2012 and 2013. The toxic fires continue 365 days a year, 24 hours a day. In 32 municipalities in the province of Naples, mortality exceeds the regional average of 10% for men and 13% for women, while in 23 municipalities in the province of Caserta the percentages are 4% and 6%. With its 500,000 hectares of agricultural area, Campania, together with Puglia and Catalonia, represents one of the three great European agri-food centers. An incalculable economic and image damage, despite the fact that the sites where toxic material has spilled do not exceed 1% of the total of rural areas. However, I must say that after decades of commissioners, during which some of us have asked several times, sometimes even in isolation, the mapping of areas at risk, the start of a process of remediation of polluted soils and the establishment of a regional cancer register, a reversal of the trend begins. Fortunately, the approach to the problem has changed: there is greater awareness and a strong determination to solve the problem at its root. Recently the Campania Region has adopted a rigorous certification procedure of the healthiness of its agri-food productions, so as to be one of the most controlled regions in Europe, and has set up a real monitoring plan for the entire Campania region, with the aim of carrying out technical surveys for the mapping - also by means of remote sensing tools - of the land in the region intended for agriculture. In February, the childhood cancer registry of the Campania Region was accredited by the Italian Association of Cancer Registries and a specific study was launched by the Zooprophylactic Institute and the Cancer Institute of Naples on 4 200 subjects from 168 municipalities identified on the basis of three different models of environmental risk, in order to exclude interference caused by low exposure or physiologically linked to age. Furthermore, the first reclamation interventions of the polluted areas were carried out. The operation to remove the eco-bales has begun, but above all Campania has adopted a new waste plan, which will have to ferry the region definitively beyond the emergency. Certainly it is necessary to do much more, to continue to keep the national, and not just national, spotlight on this huge problem that continues to claim innocent victims. The institutions, which have to demonstrate their ability to intervene, must do their part by providing for remediation quickly, but Europe can and must also do its part, accompanying Campania in this process. A few months ago, in a conference that saw the presence of doctors and scientists from all over Europe, I asked some officials of the Commission - and I repeat my request here - to draw up a manual of good practices, from hygiene-food, medical and prevention ones, to give valid indications to citizens who live in all areas with a high environmental impact in Europe. The Land of Fires, together with the many areas suffering from an environmental emergency, must not be considered or perceived as an exclusively Italian or Campania problem: it is a European emergency. The problems are multiple, complex and interconnected, and the synergy between European institutions and local authorities in recent years has been the real key to achieving tangible results. I thank Commissioner Vella for the usual willingness he shows every time we talk about Terra dei fuochi and Campania and for the involvement he has shown on several occasions. Thanks also to the associations and institutions of the Campania region, to the thousands of citizens involved in this attempt to save a wonderful land. Now it is only a question of continuing to work hard and together, so that the Terra di lavoro returns as soon as possible "Campania felix". (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

text: Dear Colleagues!We have a little more air today.Ms. Grapini asked why I didn't give her the floor for the blue card.I uphold certain principles.In any case, it is not usual for me to ask questions within the same group because we have already seen effects here that colleagues throw the balls at each other.And that's not the kind of liveliness of the debate we envisioned when we launched the blue card.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Mr. President, I would like to begin in solidarity with the Italian friends who asked this question with those who spoke, who live in Italy, who live in Campania, aware of the fact that living in such an environment is not easy, it is politically responsible, it is responsible for every way especially in a human way. Knowing that in our very question today, Commissioner, we are talking about the fact that la Terra dei Fuochi is an area in Campania where there are approximately 2,000 extremely polluted sites that directly affect the lives of 2 and a half million people who are reportedly dying from cancer. or are exposed to truly toxic fires. It’s a really serious question of how we intend to solve it all together. The area includes as many as 57 municipalities between Naples and Caserta. An additional problem is that no one knows where this toxic waste is buried at all, whether it is in one place, in another place, it has been done for years. Everything speaks of organized crime, but not only organized crime, but also dumping in a really extremely wild way. What is most worrying, of course, is that all of this together has a terrible impact on public health. It is frightening to hear the data we have been listening to, and it is especially frightening to know that public health cannot help children, it cannot help those who need growth the most. So young people, children are suffering because we have these toxic fires. What I want to emphasize is something else. I want to talk about how to solve such problems. My experience tells me that solving such problems can be done with European money. I have concrete examples that I have personally worked on in rehabilitating and identifying 46 illegal dumpsites that were, or are still partially, on the border between Croatia and Slovenia. With joint funds, European funds, joint efforts, we managed to find all these common illegal dumpsites and start solving them systematically so that so I say one by one. NGOs should be involved. In creating the cadastre of wild dumps, I have personally included scouts, mountaineers, all those associations that are benevolent towards the environment and that want to actively participate in all of this. We identified that cadastre in such a way that there is a GPS destination for each illegal dump. And then one can systematically start solving such problems. Of course, I want to emphasize here not only the way of cross-border cooperation, because in this particular case we do not even have it, but I want to emphasize the need for cooperation with local authorities. Without the active participation of local authorities, neither national nor regional, let alone European authorities can do anything. Yes, we need European money, because without European money, local, national and regional authorities will not be able to cope easily. But we need good partners in local authorities, in non-governmental organizations, because without them I am sure that we will find it very difficult to solve problems. I would like to warn you and take this opportunity, Mr. Commissioner, to mention to you the many black spots that we call in Croatia that exist in the environment. There are in the environment not only in Croatia, but also in the candidate countries, there are many wild dumps in many places, many dangerous dumps. It is time to make this cadastre of the most dangerous landfills in the European Union and in our first neighborhood in countries that will very soon one day become members of the European Union. So, I want to warn you about one big problem, and that is the problem of dumping military material in the Adriatic Sea. This is an extremely serious problem. Nobody talks about it anywhere and we all somehow hide and don’t want to talk about it in public. But it is a serious environmental problem. So, I think that the colleagues who opened this issue in this way showed their desire and solidarity with the citizens of Campania. I want to confirm this once again here, but I want to ask the European Commission to get serious about the example of Campania, let this be the beginning of solving the overall problem with such illegal landfills for hazardous waste in the European Union.The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising a blue card (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)

name: Eleonora Forenza
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I want to thank my colleagues and colleagues for submitting this question. I believe it is essential that Parliament and the European Commission address this issue, which we can no longer certainly call an emergency, given the long period of time that has elapsed. And I would like to answer, to those who spoke of an exclusive competence of the Member States with respect to the problems we are discussing, that the right to health is a fundamental right guaranteed in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, just as the precautionary principle should be a guiding principle of the action of the Commission, Parliament and Council. Here we are talking about a question of denied environmental justice, in front of which no screen can be made, the exclusive competence of the Member State cannot be used as an alibi, although we are the first to want to name what are the responsibilities of the Italian government and of the local government. We are talking, as was already said in the interventions that preceded me, of an expression, that of "Land of fires", which began in the 2000s to become commonly used, but in reality the problem we are talking about, that of illegal dumping of special and toxic waste in the area between the provinces of Naples and Caserta, dates back to at least the mid-1970s, and investigators such as Roberto Mancini had already highlighted the problem. I would like to remind you that a piece of the development of small and medium-sized industries in Northern Italy was also built on the tax-free spillage of processing waste in the land of the Terra dei Fuochi, with the mediation of organized crime, which used land, quarries and transport of waste to organize traffic. Therefore, finding oneself in an emergency situation is still a fact politically and morally today unacceptable. Personally, I am in contact, like other colleagues here in the Chamber, with the committees that deal with defending environmental justice in the Land of Fires, and that underline the effectiveness to date of the mapping, monitoring and remediation measures provided for by Italian law 6 / 2014e and implemented by the government and the Campania Region. There are no operational reclamation projects, there is no accurate analysis of the pollution of the aquifers, entire areas such as the one including the Vesuvius national park are not covered by monitoring. At cava dei Many, for example, in the municipality of Maddaloni, it is estimated that there are 200 000 cubic meters of chemical waste already characterized, but the situation is at a standstill and not only an operational remediation plan is missing, but also safety measures. There is also a lack of agricultural requalification plans for polluted land, with serious economic damage for the populations. It is also necessary to focus epidemiological and toxicological tests on the people living within the site of national interest and not extend them to the whole region, with the risk of minimizing the scope of the results. The mothers of the "Victims of the Land of Fires" committee denounced the deaths from leukemia, in the last four months alone, of 16 children, of which 80% resident in the Land of Fires. From this point of view we find shameful the words of the minister - indeed the minister - of health Lorenzin of 2015, who dared to affirm that the highest death rate in Campania was due to vehicle pollution, a bad health system and lifestyles and wrong power supply. We are truly speechless, because this means ignoring the heaviness and gravity of the problem we are talking about. So I thank once again the colleagues who presented this question, a more than legitimate question, if we consider that the European Commission fined Italy for 22 million last year. February and that, after the sentence of the European Court of 2015 precisely for the waste emergency in Campania and the non-compliance with directives 98/2008 and others on the treatment and recycling of waste, after all this it is still difficult to impose a decisive measure to this problem. So it is also necessary to make up for what the Member State, the Italian government, is still struggling to do, precisely because the health of citizens is at stake and the right to health is a fundamental right. I just want to add that I believe it is not enough - indeed, I believe it is deeply wrong - to transform a problem of an economic-social order, of environmental justice of national scope, into a problem of public order, into a problem simply of repression and management of waste flows. . The militarization of many of these sites has simply too often prevented committees, militants and experts from being able to adequately guard the polluted sites. I think that the solutions must be fundamental, they must be long-term solutions, but they must also be immediate solutions because, precisely, we are talking about deaths, we are talking about economic damage, we are talking about a social damage that insists on an area in which the female unemployment and youth unemployment is at very high levels. Immediately applicable measures are also possible to reduce the extent of spills and contain the phenomenon of fires. It is necessary to implement protocols to do secondary prevention, that is to detoxify from absorbed pollutants and above all to do primary prevention.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Land of Fires is one of the most dramatic situations in my country, but also in Europe as a whole. We are talking about real mass poisonings with public participation. Yes, because they both have one thing in common: the state. In the Land of Fires from 1991 to 2013 there were 80 investigations for illegal trafficking of toxic waste, 2,000 complaints, 500 companies involved, 95 defendants in various capacities, including environmental disaster and multiple culpable homicide. Obviously, a prescription for everyone. Between Caserta and Naples, cancer deaths far exceed any national and foreign average. The State has known the situation for years: already at the end of 2013, with a decree to deal with environmental and industrial emergencies, it had established the need to carry out health screenings to be sure of the correlation between deaths and Terra dei Fuochi - as if there were any need - screening, however, then discontinued, because resources have been halved. But the government, in the context of the so-called "empty prisons" policy, has effectively nullified this decree and made the sentence for those who apply real death pyres aleatory. The government thus demonstrates that it has ignored that the right to the environment is a constitutive element of the right to health, which the Constitution protects as a primary right with its article 32, thus making itself repeatedly in arrears with respect to the fulfillment of both Community and constitutional obligations. despite numerous warnings from the European Court of Justice. And the citizens therefore pay, and not only with the European fine of 120 000 euros a day, but with what is most important: their lives and the lives of their children. The government must provide a different perspective to the inhabitants of the contaminated areas, transforming criticality into opportunity. But here is the proposal: the European Commission becomes a promoter - one: of the creation of centers for international research, perhaps based in Southern Italy, dealing with both new remediation technologies and the decision-making process to identify them;guidance centers for an expanding sector.Two: since in Italy, and in Europe, many sites remain abandoned and polluted without the person responsible being identified and reclaimed, we ask that a European fund financed by polluting industries, such as the EPA superfund, be set up.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, dear colleagues, I had to be present. First, to accompany our Italian friends; then, as a member of Strasbourg, it is also a duty to be there to make this session of Parliament on Thursday afternoon real, which nevertheless seems difficult when compared to a Thursday afternoon in Brussels; finally, because I really like the Naples region, having sailed there a lot, and because it is an absolutely beautiful region. I would like us to raise the debate a bit on the question of the diversion of European funds into the Mafia and ask ourselves the question of the procedures that allowed this. Of course - and I will come back to this - there is a responsibility for Italy in delegating the management of these funds, but there is a more global problem. I note - I turn to the Commission - that either we are in extremely complicated procedures where, fearing any misappropriation of funds, we are no longer able to spend the funds. To illustrate my point, I will quote the G5 Sahel, for which we voted 15 billion, which are absolutely necessary for the fight for security and development in this area, but the procedures put in place are such that we do not spend money for fear of embezzlement. There is a problem. Either we are faced with protocols, ethical charters, codes of good conduct, principles of transparency, disclosures of conflicts of interest, and so on, open calls for tenders and, despite everything , we see this permanent misappropriation of funds. Why have we come to this? I think you in the Commission should ask yourself some questions. How to adapt procedures to the real world and to the real situation? Because it is very easy to make calls for tenders in which there is embezzlement or misappropriation of funds. This should have been anticipated, because it is still unacceptable that we arrive, by European funds, to support organized crime. Certainly what you are proposing is very good. We sanction, we give back money to help put things back in place, but won't this donated money be diverted again? In Italy, we face the same situation as we have in very difficult countries - and I am thinking particularly of the Albanian Mafia, in Kosovo, in Bosnia-Herzegovina or even in Serbia, in all these enlargement countries. -, where Community funds - and you know this - are also misappropriated to support organized crime movements. We need to rethink these procedures. I would like to come back to my experience: when I worked with the mayor of Strasbourg in 1980, the services were public and we had control of our waste, which avoided any misuse of the procedure since the city was responsible and managed itself. , under its own control, all the management of its waste. The generalized calls for tenders, the liberalization according to which it was necessary to put in competition have particularly led to such a situation of diversion of the procedure by fictitious companies, by front companies for the benefit of organizations and organized crime or, quite simply. , of companies that make absolutely unacceptable profits. It all worked very well in Strasbourg, I give the example, when we did it on our own. Second thing: the weakening of the State, the way in which the State has been prevented, the withdrawal of its sovereignty, the inability it really has to be able to use the means, often by force, with regard to organized crime. There are not only elements of law, there is also the monopoly of force, and we have entered a circuit so complicated that we do not come out because we have weakened States. Finally, to conclude, the Commission must reflect on procedures linked to reality.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in the 1600s, when Naples was experiencing its golden age, it was known as the most fertile plain in the world. In the past 20 years, however, Naples and the Campania district have had new nicknames: ‘Land of Poison’, ‘Triangle of Death’, ‘Land of Fires’. The latter, of course, refers to the region of Campania where toxic wastes have been illegally burned and buried in a systematic fashion since the late 1980s. This is environmental sabotage on a grand scale. From 1994 to 2008 the region of Campania in south-west Italy was under a formal state of emergency declared due to the saturation of regional waste treatment facilities. There is growing evidence, including from the World Health Organisation, that the accumulation of waste, illegal and legal, urban and industrial, has contaminated soil, water and the air with a range of toxic pollutants, including dioxins. It has even emerged that the United States Navy, whose European Command is based in Naples, conducted a USD 30 million study from 2008-2011 into local air, soil and water. They found unacceptable health risks and advised their personnel accordingly. Throughout all the research, a high correlation between incidence of cancer, respiratory illnesses and genetic malformations and the presence of industrial and toxic waste landfills has been found. Reported cases include women getting breast cancer unusually early, men developing lung cancer despite never having smoked, and children born with Down’s Syndrome to comparatively young mothers. All this is very, very worrying. Many people say that the catalyst for this catastrophe is illegal trade and that hazardous waste is a by—product of tax dodging in a country with one of the highest levels of evasion in western Europe. Businesses massaging their income had to mask the scale of their activities and that meant hiding huge amounts of hazardous waste. Yet some people’s solution to this is to blame the European Union and, above all, the Commission. There is a phrase, ‘where there is a will, there is a way’, but you could also say, ‘where there is no political will, there is undue delay’. Commissioner Vella has pointed out the efforts they have made to help. The European Court of Justice fined Italy EUR 40 million, which they paid in 2015, and again another EUR 40 million in late 2015, again EUR 20 million, and, as has been mentioned, EUR 120 000 daily. But all the fines in the world will not solve the problem unless there is a real, genuine effort and the political will to do so. The Commission is prepared to give EUR 172 million, but it can only act within the Treaties and the powers given to it. So I think there is need for fresh thinking and here and for cooperation so that the Land of Fires can once again become the most fertile plain in the world and a great place to live.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the discussion we are having here today is very important, and I thank my colleagues Pedicini and others, who have solicited this reflection. But let's not waste this opportunity and let's try to make a reflection together with Commissioner Vella that will allow us to take a few steps forward with respect to a story of which we know all the aspects. There is nothing we do not know about what has happened in the last 25, 30, 35 years, in our land. We know the original accumulation of organized crime, which made the exchange with northern companies the beginning, in the seventies and eighties, of what then became the Land of Fires. We also know the responsibilities of many productive forces of that territory, which have continued to use those areas for illegal landfills. We know the very painful responsibilities of politics, starting with my political side. But if we continue to hurt ourselves only, to argue, and we do not try to seize the opportunities that national, regional, local and European institutions allow us from time to time to reopen this dossier and make, of these occasions, opportunities to make a step forward precisely to respond to the needs we have before us, first of all the health needs we have in that area, and also to relaunch the productive and civil image of that area, so we waste our time. Maybe we gain some personal consensus, but we don't take any steps forward. We have a knowledge of reality like never before. We know where the polluting sites are, or at least most of them: we have monitored them, we finally have a map. We have a health report. Then we can discuss the methodologies, and there is also a further update, but we know that the problem exists and that it mainly concerns our children. And we have a law enforcement action underway. If I mention only the things that have been done in the last months of 2016 to counter what is now happening in that territory, from the arrests, to the checks, to the fines that have been made, to the attempt to stop an illegal spill on those areas again, we realize that an action, an initiative is underway. We finally have a waste collection and disposal plan - I know they are discussing it with you right now. And for the first time - I tell my colleague D'Amato - we have huge resources at our disposal. This had never happened before. We have national resources, we have European resources. So we must try to build the conditions so that this time, really, this opportunity is not a missed opportunity. We no longer have to return to this House in the coming months to tell ourselves about a defeat, because having the knowledge, having the tools and also having the resources available, we then go back to denouncing the absence of initiatives. Then all that can be done: first of all a stronger concentration of institutions, but also an accompaniment. Here I would like to propose three simple things. In agreement with the other parliamentarians, we come back here every six months - perhaps we use the Committee on the Environment - and we take stock of the situation every six months. Because this question must be addressed, it cannot become the subject of a political campaign every time. Every six months, to identify responsibilities and things that have not been done. I would like to invite Commissioner Vella to come to Campania to meet the authorities and to make a point on the state of the start of the reclamation program, in terms of health. Make a real point, of the real state of things. And see together what to do, because on this I agree with all my colleagues who have said it: we cannot just have a Europe that imposes fines and that's it. And finally, I agree with my colleague D'Amato's proposal: let's work for a research center.We have three important reclamation poles in Southern Italy: Taranto, Crotone and Terra dei fuochi.It is important to have a scientific investment in the territory of the South, because it can be of help to this enormous program, which we must carry out, of reclamation of our territories, and it can also be a winning choice on the ground even of a stronger relationship between science, innovation and eco-friendly development.Here, I believe that this is a way to face and to try to give a positive response to a huge challenge that lies ahead of us, and it would be really dramatic if in the coming months we came back here to discuss as if nothing had happened.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank the Commissioner and my colleagues: my colleague Pedicini, the colleagues who, with their questioning, offer us this important opportunity to discuss here, today, on this serious, long-standing issue, serious that is the question "Land of fires". Colleagues, you have said this by now, but it is no less serious for this, no less painful for this. As you have already said and as I want to remember, this question has the face of the hundreds and hundreds of people, women, children who in these long years have fallen ill due to the spill of waste, which was operated illegally by the clans Camorra, of course, but also from a certain underground economy, which we should also discuss. It is a serious and painful issue, as I said, because there is an evident and recognized correlation between illegal waste spillage and these cancers: I will not quote here all the scientific literature that reminds us of this correlation - we have all supported it, you have said it before me - and so I just call her back. I was saying, it is a known issue because - colleagues, president, commissioner - we have been discussing this issue for twenty years now. The "Adelphi" operation, which ascertained for the first time the role of the Bidognetti clan through Gaetano Cerci, through the controversial and very dangerous figure of Cipriano Chianese, dates back to 1991. In 1995, during the trial of the Avolio +19 criminal proceedings, the repentant Schiavone was heard, for the first time, who indicated, in that trial, the places - you will remember - where the waste that he said radioactive should be buried. Then there was an action, after those declarations, as a consequence of those declarations, there was an initiative of the Criminalpol of Rome on the delegation of the Neapolitan Public Prosecutor's Office, which started a series of inspections, a series of inspections in the sites indicated by Schiavone. But the radioactive waste has never been found, has never been identified, as Federico Cafiero De Raho has repeatedly reiterated, who at the time, I want to remind you, was the head of the Naples DDA. Twenty years, then. In these twenty years many things have been said, perhaps not all by the way: we have listened to many approximate things, to the point of witnessing a kind of pernicious short circuit, at one point - I remembered the case of radioactive waste never identified. A pernicious short circuit, which at a certain point seemed to pursue more a request for sensationalism at all costs than the real, precise, dutiful reconstruction of the facts. And in some cases, colleagues, we have even reached the paroxysm - I want to remember - with repentant Camorrists who accused magistrates of telling lies. This also happened. And then, colleagues, we must impose ourselves, in this discussion, so that it is really useful, because it is constructive, meanwhile, respect for the facts, the precise, meticulous, dutiful reconstruction of the truth. And the truth requires us to say that the matter is very serious and very serious, the largest slaughter of innocent victims that has ever occurred in that area of ​​the country, certainly. But we cannot fail to say that there are so many steps forward, in short, we must recognize that finally, after years of guilty silences, after years of inability to act, the Italian government, the local authorities, I like to say "the Italian State" they are working well, also in collaboration with the European Commission. I want to remember the most important things. Law 68 of 2015, which introduced a new title dedicated to crimes against the environment into the criminal code, is working, it is working because the data processed by the ecomafie commission tells us that it works. Just as we can recognize that the territory is garrisoned, that we are working seriously on reclamation, starting from the areas more delicate.In short, so much is being done and so much must continue to do, as we are doing, leaving behind these twenty years of inability and silence and continuing on the path we have taken and which I believe will finally lead us to the resolution of this very serious problem for the'Italy and for Europe.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I do not want to resume my colleagues' debates. I agree that waste affects people's lives and affects it in the long run and for generations. I want us to think of solutions. I was surprised to see that the Commission has left a loophole in the waste directive so that hazardous waste is not registered. Shipments of less than two tonnes of hazardous waste and twenty tonnes of non-hazardous waste may pass without being registered. We need exact traceability, because it can be a carrier with two tons of hazardous waste, but it can be a thousand carriers with two tons per year and then, think that we are moving the foci of infection from one country to another. . I believe that here we need to think about immediate solutions, how we can stop, but especially in the long term. Commissioner, maybe you are thinking of devoting a lot of research to waste disposal technology, because I don't think we have a very clear record now: what types of waste we have and what technology we have to destroy them and not affect people's lives. .

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I agree with my colleagues that this was a very good opportunity to discuss this great, huge, alarming, chronic problem – and I call it chronic because we act, we discuss, we act and discuss, and the problem goes on and on. The Commission is very much aware of the worrying situation caused by the sub-standard and illegal waste management in Campania over the years and has already acted consequently and comprehensively, for over more than 10 years now. The Commission has done its maximum within its legal powers and will continue to do its utmost to curb the situation. However, strict enforcement of relevant legislation by the Italian competent authorities is paramount to eradicate an environmental and health problem which is instigated by organised crime, and maybe some MEPs know more than others and accept and admit more than others what is actually going on.  I agree with those who said that the citizens are not only paying with their taxes, but more so, they are paying with their health. Mr Pedicini asked whether the infringement procedure works and I must say, yes, it does work. It works in other Member States. It also works in other sectors in Italy itself, so why should it not work in Italy for this sector? I have to say that even here, as I mentioned before, there was progress in this sector, there was improvement, as a colleague mentioned, that the Italian authorities in December presented a management plan which my services are assessing. I was also a bit surprised that, in this letter that we signed, we talk about waste, we talk about health, but very little about the root of the problem, the criminal activity for which the state and the citizens are paying and against which we all have to act.  We talked about funding. I do not think that we are addressing an issue of lack of funds here. Funding was available. I also mentioned that EUR 72 million was provided in the current financial framework, but funding alone will not do the job. We also need the political goodwill of all the authorities, of all the parties, to fight the root cause of these problems. We have only heard about what the EU should do when the EU has already done a lot, without naming and shaming the illegal activities. If we continue to discuss only the Commission and the EU without addressing and shaming what the real cause is, I think this will only encourage the illegal activities to go on.  And let us not underestimate the scale of this illegal activity because the waste problem in the Campania region has been characterised by illegality, inefficiency, irresponsibility and indecision. It is a much more complex phenomenon than it seems and unfortunately it has been inadequately addressed by policymakers.  As I said before, I can assure you that my services and all the Commission will keep monitoring the situation in Campania to verify that the Italian authorities are taking the necessary measures to ensure that the waste is managed without endangering human health and the environment in accordance with EU waste legislation. I need to stress again, however, that the solution to the acute health problems derived from the illegal treatment of waste in Campania is dependent on all relevant actors working effectively together. It is paramount that the Italian competent authorities take a firm hold of the situation and clamp down on organised crime in order to dissociate it from waste management. I think we can all be of service to our citizens not only by discussing the problem, but by actively working together to address again the root cause of it all. We know what the problem is, we know what we have to do so, let us do it. Let us act to solve the problem and not continue discussing it in aeternum.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That closes the debate.
